EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th accumulated to between 2 and 3 inches. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper brought a quick round of snow to central Indiana during the evening of January 5 and the early morning hours of January 6. The snow combined with the cold temperatures caused roads to become slick and hazardous for the morning commute. Snowfall amounts were heaviest north of Indianapolis, quickly tapering off to less than an inch south of Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulation observations ranged from 5.5 to 7 inches in and near the Anderson area. No other information on impacts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper brought a quick round of snow to central Indiana during the evening of January 5 and the early morning hours of January 6. Snowfall amounts were heaviest north of Indianapolis, quickly tapering off to less than an inch south of Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulation observations ranged from 4.5 to 6 inches across much of the county. The highest amounts came from just south of Muncie. No other information on impacts were received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulation of 5.7 inches was reported from 2.6 miles northeast of McCordsville. No other information on impacts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance produced freezing rain across central Indiana during the evening of January 11 and early morning of January 12 across central Indiana. Most of the freezing rain fell north of I-70, where 0.1 to 0.2 inches of ice were common. Temperatures around freezing helped keep areas south of I-70 from accumulating a lot of ice. As colder air moved in during the early morning of January 12, some accumulating light snow fell across far northern sections of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three tenths of an inch of freezing rain had accumulated in the Anderson area by within an hour after midnight during the early morning of the 12th of January. No other impacts were noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed ahead of an ejecting upper system over the lower Ohio Valley and raced northeast into the region. A second squall line developed and trailed the first one by an hour or so.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was knocked down across Sanes Rd. near W. Johnson School Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed ahead of an ejecting upper system over the lower Ohio Valley and raced northeast into the region. A second squall line developed and trailed the first one by an hour or so.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One healthy tree was uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed ahead of an ejecting upper system over the lower Ohio Valley and raced northeast into the region. A second squall line developed and trailed the first one by an hour or so.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two 2 1/2 foot diameter pine trees were knocked down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed ahead of an ejecting upper system over the lower Ohio Valley and raced northeast into the region. A second squall line developed and trailed the first one by an hour or so.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were knocked down along Route 229 as well as on Weatherman Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was knocked down onto a house.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power was temporarily lost at the residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into Friday morning accumulated to between 2 and 5 inches. Wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow also created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into Friday afternoon, with a few roads becoming impassible. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of freezing rain began Sunday evening and continued into Monday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EMA reported a tenth of an inch of ice (glaze) and two tenths of an inch of sleet accumulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving Alberta Clipper dropped a quick 2 to 5 inches of snow on northern Indiana late in the evening on January 5th into the early morning hours of January 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light to moderate snow with reduced visibilities accumulated to between 4 and 5 inches late January 5th into early January 6th. Cold temperatures near 10 degrees allowed the snow to accumulate on area roadways which created difficult travel conditions in time for the morning commute. There were reports of slide-offs, accidents, and school delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A light, fluffy one to two inches of snow fell on top of the snowcover from the February 16 winter storm. The new snow produced a fresh coating on top of already cleared roads, and additional snow on top of unplowed streets and back roads. Gusty winds caused some blowing of the snow. A disturbance in the upper levels of the atmosphere moved southeast across the Lower Ohio Valley. The fast-moving disturbance had little moisture to work with, but it was strong enough to squeeze out minor snow accumulations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow accompanied by gusty winds and bitterly cold wind chills impacted far northern Indiana on January 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands developed during the early morning hours of January 7th and persisted through much of the day. Total snow accumulations across the country generally ranged between 2 and 4 inches. The falling snow and wind gusts of 25 to 30 mph reduced visibilities and created areas of blowing and drifting snow. Wind chills during the event generally ranged between 5 below zero and 15 below zero. There were school delays along with reports of slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th only accumulated to around inch. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 50 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic airmass across the region brought single digit highs and below zero lows several days in a row in early January.  The coldest period was January 7th through 8th.  The low temperature at O'Hare on the 7th was -6ÔøΩÔøΩF with a high of 6ÔøΩÔøΩF.  On the 8th, the temperature fell to -8ÔøΩÔøΩF.  Wind chills that morning were also quite frigid with numerous sites reporting -20ÔøΩÔøΩF to around -30ÔøΩÔøΩF.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front dropping south from the Great Lakes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous full sized trees and power lines were knocked down in and around Richmond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper brought a quick round of snow to central Indiana during the evening of January 5 and the early morning hours of January 6. The snow combined with the cold temperatures caused roads to become slick and hazardous for the morning commute. Snowfall amounts were heaviest north of Indianapolis, quickly tapering off to less than an inch south of Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall accumulation observations ranging from 5.5 to 7.5 inches were reported from across the county. No other information on impacts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer located 4 miles northeast of Osgood and the emergency manager in Batesville both measured 4/10 of an inch of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inches of snow was reported in the far southeast of the county by the sheriff in Rockdale. The cooperative observer in Brookville measured 1.3 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Alpine measured 3 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EMA in Liberty measured 4 inches of snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EMA in Richmond measured 5 inches of snowfall while the CoCoRaHS observer 5 miles north of town measured 4.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked east along the Ohio River and interacted with an upper level disturbance to wring out 4 to 5 inches of snow over the northern Whitewater valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report from Vevay indicated that a half inch of snow had fallen.

Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front dropping south from the Great Lakes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large limbs and trees were knocked down along Wernie Road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was uprooted.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was snapped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed as a low pressure center tracked east along a stationary front which was draped across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Part of Retherford Road was closed due to high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper brought a quick round of snow to central Indiana during the evening of January 5 and the early morning hours of January 6. The snow combined with the cold temperatures caused roads to become slick and hazardous for the morning commute. Snowfall amounts were heaviest north of Indianapolis, quickly tapering off to less than an inch south of Indianapolis.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple snowfall accumulation observations around 6 to 6.5 inches were reported from in and near the Frankfort area. No other information on impacts were received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th only accumulated to around inch. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th only accumulated to between 1 and 2 inches. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quick-moving Alberta Clipper brought a quick burst of snow, strong winds, reduced visibilities, and significant blowing snow to the region late January 8th into January 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of snow during the late afternoon hours of January 8th into the early morning hours of January 9th accumulated to between 1 and 3 inches. However, wind gusts ranging between 30 and 40 mph in tandem with the falling snow created whiteout conditions at times. Significant blowing and drifting of the snow created additional travel problems across mainly open and rural areas into the day on Friday. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region, along with numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Upper level energy moved into the region, helping initiate convection north of a decaying mesoscale convective system across central and southern Illinois. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a empty semi trailer was blown off the road by high winds on Interstate 69, near mile marker 334. The driver sustained minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported several trees down 1 mile east of Elon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that a boat and trailer were flipped over due to severe thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

An intense storm system brought flooding rains to southern Indiana, followed quickly by very heavy snow. The upper level pattern featured a positively tilted upper low across the desert southwest on the 3nd of March. A tight baroclinic zone stretched northeastward through southern Indiana. Strong southwesterly flow at lower levels brought rich moisture along this nearly stationary boundary. Initially, during the evening hours on the 3nd, rain developed along this boundary and gradually overspread all of southern Indiana and central Kentucky. Steady rain continued through the late afternoon on the 4th. One to two inches of rain fell across southern Indiana before precipitation changed into snow during the mid afternoon hours. Minor areal flooding developed across southern Indiana with several roads and low water crossings closed. ||Rain quickly changed to snow as a cold front moved south into Kentucky. Heavy snow fell from mid afternoon on the 4th through the early morning hours of the next day. Snowfall amounts ranged from around 5 inches in northern sections of Dubois, Orange, and Jefferson Counties to just under one foot along the Ohio River southwest of Louisville. This snow fell at a very fast rate, with very low visibilities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eleven inches of snow was measured in Tell City. Lessor amounts of snow fell across northern portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate instability was in place across much of northern Indiana as a cold front swept through the area. Shear was marginal but sufficient to help organize some of the convection with the strongest cells producing narrow areas of wind damage or borderline severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree and power line down across the road at Division Road and County Road 200 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain bands associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Bill produced isolated strong winds and very heavy rain. The convective character of the bands increased during the afternoon due to short intervals of sunshine that destabilized the atmosphere. The surface low pressure center that constituted the remnants of Bill was located over the extreme southeast corner of Missouri during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down near Highway 57 just west of the Interstate 69 interchange.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed along an old thunderstorm outflow boundary over southern Illinois and western Kentucky. The storms congealed into a mass of heavy rain as they propagated east across southwest Indiana in the evening. Late at night, another mesoscale convective system increased in size as it moved southeast across southwest Indiana. This second system produced isolated flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street flooding was reported. A spotter reported 1.3 inches of rain in one hour on the southeast side of Evansville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that water 12 inches deep was swiftly moving over Shirley Avenue. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain fell on top of saturated ground.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that Dovir Wood Rd and County Line Rd were flooded. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain fell across the county, on top of very saturated ground.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that many roads were flooded as streams were running out of their banks. Around 2 inches of rain fell across the county, on top of saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms formed along a weakening convective outflow boundary as it moved southeast across the Lower Ohio Valley. Locally heavy rainfall occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 1.5 inches of rain in 40 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another subtle weather disturbance pushed through the Ohio Valley on the afternoon and evening of April 8th.  This disturbance interacted with a very moist and unstable airmass, characterized by temperatures in the upper 70s and 80s.  Supercell thunderstorms developed across parts of the area, producing hail across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported hail up to the size of pennys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The combination of a warm, humid air mass an approaching cold front to the northwest of the area produced scattered strong to severe thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry County emergency manager reported 1 inch hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Perry County emergency manager reported numerous trees down with damage to vehicles.

A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed that 1 inch diameter hail fell in Clarksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported that because of heavy rainfall, Otter Creek was out of its bank and running over Otter Creek Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported numerous roads were impassable due to flood waters. Between 4 and 5 inches of rain fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the heavy snow, heavy rain and subsequent snow melt of March 4-5, additional rainfall March 7 - 11 continued minor river flooding across southern Indiana. This resulted in the Ohio River to rise above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall during the previous 2 to 3 weeks brought the Ohio River at Cannelton Lock and Dam into flood. The river crested at 47.33 feet during the morning hours of March 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water over State Route 64 near Huntingburg. Between 4 and 5 inches of rain were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed along a frontal boundary stretched from northeast to southwest in central Indiana during the afternoon and evening of April the 2nd. A few of these storms produced large hail and one damaging wind report.

Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed along a frontal boundary stretched from northeast to southwest in central Indiana during the afternoon and evening of April the 2nd. A few of these storms produced large hail and one damaging wind report.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The size of the hail was determined from a photo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following the heavy snow, heavy rain and subsequent snow melt of March 4-5, additional rainfall March 7 - 11 continued minor river flooding across southern Indiana. This resulted in the Ohio River to rise above flood stage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An unusually wet period with repeated rounds of heavy rain brought the Ohio River at Tell City into a long duration flood. The river went above flood stage March 7th, crested on March 17th and then fell below flood stage March 23rd.

Snowfall amounts ranged from around 5 inches in northern sections of Dubois, Orange, and Jefferson Counties to just under one foot along the Ohio River southwest of Louisville. This snow fell at a very fast rate, with very low visibilities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 7 inches of snow fell near Paoli.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated damaging wind gusts occurred with bands of northeastward moving thunderstorms. Weak to moderate instability and deep, unidirectional southwesterly flow aloft helped to maintain the storms. A 500 mb shortwave trough over the Ozarks moved northeast to the vicinity of the Ohio and Mississippi River confluence by mid-afternoon. A weak surface low pressure center moved northeast from southeast Missouri into south central Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were blown down onto roads from Griffin to the Wadesville area. One of the trees landed on Route 66.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Transportation officials reported nickel size hail fell in Schnellville.

An intense storm system brought flooding rains to southern Indiana, followed quickly by very heavy snow. The upper level pattern featured a positively tilted upper low across the desert southwest on the 3nd of March. A tight baroclinic zone stretched northeastward through southern Indiana. Strong southwesterly flow at lower levels brought rich moisture along this nearly stationary boundary. Initially, during the evening hours on the 3nd, rain developed along this boundary and gradually overspread all of southern Indiana and central Kentucky. Steady rain continued through the late afternoon on the 4th. One to two inches of rain fell across southern Indiana before precipitation changed into snow during the mid afternoon hours. Minor areal flooding developed across southern Indiana with several roads and low water crossings closed. ||Rain quickly changed to snow as a cold front moved south into Kentucky. Heavy snow fell from mid afternoon on the 4th through the early morning hours of the next day. Snowfall amounts ranged from around 5 inches in northern sections of Dubois, Orange, and Jefferson Counties to just under one foot along the Ohio River southwest of Louisville. This snow fell at a very fast rate, with very low visibilities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads were closed briefly in English as Bird Hollow Creek overflowed its banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A live, 18-inch diameter tree branch was downed on State Road 234 due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rain bands associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Bill produced isolated strong winds and very heavy rain. The convective character of the bands increased during the afternoon due to short intervals of sunshine that destabilized the atmosphere. The surface low pressure center that constituted the remnants of Bill was located over the extreme southeast corner of Missouri during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several highway exits throughout the city of Evansville were flooded. A few rural roadways outside the city were shut down. Creeks and ditches were flowing out of their banks. The daily rainfall total for the 19th at the Evansville airport was 3.65 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: State officials reported that an unusual amount of roads had high water running over them due to heavy rainfall, forcing them to be barricaded. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell on top of very saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A soaking rain brought an average of just under 2 inches to southern Indiana during the 13th and 14th of March. Local streams and rivers, already quite high due to previous heavy rains and snow melt went into flood over the subsequent several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall over the previous 2 weeks brought the Ohio River at Clifty Creek into minor flood. The river crested at 453.1 feet on the morning of March 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain led to rapid rises on the Middle Fork Creek. This led to the washing out of State Road 250 near Lancaster.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Clusters of thunderstorms persisted well into the night ahead of a low-amplitude mid-level shortwave trough. These storms moved eastward through a corridor of very moist air, with precipitable water values approaching two inches. The convection was near and south of a surface front that extended from Iowa to southern Ohio. A few storms produced strong gusty winds and isolated large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media user posted a photo of the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado first touched down just east of Lake Celina where one tree was uprooted and others were snapped.  The tornado then continued east across IN-37 where it uprooted and snapped several dozen trees along Old IN-37.  The damage continued east towards Ottoman Road where a carport was destroyed, along with additional trees that were snapped and uprooted.  From there, the tornado took a jog to the northeast across Orchid and St. Croix Roads where it caused substantial tree damage, uprooting and/or snapping trunks 15-20 feet high on approximately 100 trees.  The tornado then lifted just east of Saint Croix Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that Frenchtown-Milltown Road closed due to fast moving high water flowing over it. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain fell on top of very saturated ground.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood damage to a couple of trailers in the town of Mecca due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.  Parke county emergency management estimated the damage at $10,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was observed at Unionville School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

A lingering front across central Indiana helped to generate thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon of April the 8th. The storms brought numerous large hail reports, a few flooding reports, and a singular observation of damaging winds.

Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in Daleville due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This report came in via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported to the NWS trees down in the area due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Floyd County emergency manager reported numerous trees down off High Street. One tree fell on a house and damaged a front porch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed to the NWS a report of a barn roof partially blown off due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A tornado-warned storm pushed southeast across Patricksburg and near Freedom in Owen County on the evening of the 21st of June. Reports of large tree limbs being down came in as this storm moved across Owen County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs were downed on a few county roads between Freedom and Spencer due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple power poles were downed at the intersection of State Route 236 and County Road 500 North due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Police and Fire departments responded. The wind and rain was strong, but no wind speed was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs from a fairly healthy tree were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Siding was blown off of two homes due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An eight-inch diameter tree was broken due to thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Small tree limbs were blown down due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant severe weather occurred in northern Illinois and in Michigan, but avoided northern Illinois. Supercells formed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 22 and moved eastward. Storms weakened as they moved into Indiana due warm mid-levels. Any storms which formed in Indiana were primarily multicellular in nature and sub-severe.

Significant severe weather occurred in northern Illinois and in Michigan, but avoided northern Illinois. Supercells formed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 22 and moved eastward. Storms weakened as they moved into Indiana due warm mid-levels. Any storms which formed in Indiana were primarily multicellular in nature and sub-severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down between 700W and 500N.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant severe weather occurred in northern Illinois and in Michigan, but avoided northern Illinois. Supercells formed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 22 and moved eastward. Storms weakened as they moved into Indiana due warm mid-levels. Any storms which formed in Indiana were primarily multicellular in nature and sub-severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down between 200W and 300N.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were downed in and just south of Parker City due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south line of scattered thunderstorms intensified as it moved through the eastern half of central Indiana, producing wind damage across a few counties in east-central Indiana during the afternoon of May the 11th. These storms occurred ahead of a frontal boundary sweeping from west to east across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down across Highway 27 near State Route 28 due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported a large gazebo was blown over and damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a large and healthy eight inch diameter tree limb was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a large tree limb, approximately one foot in diameter, was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported over a dozen trees and tree limbs were blown down along the Winona Lake Cycling and Walking trails.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch said County Road 900 West was closed between County Roads 825 South and 950 South due to high water from heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An employee with Winzerwald Winery reported golf ball sized hail. Patio furniture on the property also was blown around due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms moved into northwestern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported near 400 South and 500 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The roof of a barn was tossed across a roadway and multiple trees were down near the intersection of Owens Farm Road and County Road 60 West due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.

A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: WTHR reports that a lightning strike around 5:30 AM EDT Thursday is believed to be the cause of a house fire in the 5700 block of North Peppereel Way in McCordsville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts near the intersection of 7th and Harrison Streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were down at the intersection of State Route 236 and Rangeline Road due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. Traffic had to be rerouted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs, eight to ten inches in diameter, were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a dry first week to the month, strong to severe thunderstorms impacted central Indiana periodically throughout the remainder of June as the Ohio Valley remained in a generally unsettled weather pattern.  A humid air mass remained across central and|southern Indiana from the 11th through the 23rd.  A series of storms from the 12th through the 18th dropped 4 to more than 8 inches of rainfall in northern Indiana. A west-east line of storms developed across central Illinois and expanded eastward into central Indiana on the afternoon of June 18th, producing a few damaging wind reports.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was downed due to thunderstorm wind gusts observed at 49 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A pole barn was damaged with metal strewn out into a field due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were downed, trees were damaged, and there was damage to a structure from County Road 75 West to County Road 300 West along County Road 800 North due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down on the west side of Delphi, blocking Bicycle Bridge Road, due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large burr oak tree, four feet in diameter, lost half of its crown due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. A three-foot diameter chunk of the tree snapped and took out power lines approximately 1.5 miles north of the intersection of Highway 52 and Klondike Road. There was partial rot in the heartwood, otherwise, it was a healthy tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported numerous streets flooded in the city of Madison due to torrential and intense rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was measured on the south side of Lafayette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported many roads with high water across northern Vermillion County due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northeast to southwest oriented line of thunderstorms moved east-southeast from west-central Indiana into central Indiana during the morning hours of June 25th. These storms produced a singular wind damage and small hail report. North of these thunderstorms was a large shield of rain caused some flash flooding across northern portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was over County Road 100 West, south of State Road 32, due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of thunderstorms brought heavy rain and some severe weather to central Indiana during the evenings of June 7th and June 8th. Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front the evening of June 7th. These brought rainfall of over 3 inches to portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was downed and blocking the intersection of Amelia Avenue and Creasy Lane due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired across northern Indiana in the late afternoon. Strong upper-level forcing was adequate to overcome the relatively weak shear and instability with isolated reports of severe weather.
Storms fired across northern Indiana in the late afternoon. Strong upper-level forcing was adequate to overcome the relatively weak shear and instability with isolated reports of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One tree down, and several large limbs down. A truck was severely damaged by a large branch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired along and ahead of a cold front during the afternoon and evening hours on June 10. Weak instability and shear kept storms mostly below severe limits except for a few isolated severe storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several end segments of two center pivot irrigation systems were blown over and severely damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated thunderstorms developed across central Indiana during the afternoon of June 5th. One of these storms moved generally south-southeast into the Crothersville area causing some wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over roadways in Marshall due to heavy rainfall of 1.40 inches in 40 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported trees down across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observing station at the Indianapolis International Airport measured a 58 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS at the Indianapolis International Airport reported another thunderstorm wind gust measured at 58 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of trees down across the area was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. JulyÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩs rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the Wabash River from June through most of July. Low-lying fields, woodlands, and some oil wells were flooded in the flood plain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. JulyÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩs rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the White River from June through most of July. Because it was agricultural season, extensive flooding of river bottomlands caused significant crop damage. High water surrounded any residents in river cabins. Several streets and back roads were flooded and impassable. Oil fields were flooded. Flood gates were installed at Hazleton. A softball field was underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms initiated along a stationary front across northern Indiana. Moderate instability and weak shear led to a few wet downbursts which caused isolated wind damage. The greater threat became flooding as rainfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour became common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down across the road. Water was also running over the road.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inch healthy tree fell on power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding at the intersection of Calhoun St. and Tillman Rd. Storm drains discharging water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: From the city of Evansville east along the Ohio River, afternoon temperatures in the lower to mid 90's combined with oppressive humidity levels to create heat indices near 105 degrees. The peak heat index was 105 at Evansville.  A cold front over southwest Indiana was preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

From the city of Evansville east along the Ohio River, afternoon temperatures in the lower to mid 90's combined with oppressive humidity levels to create heat indices near 105 degrees. The peak heat index was 105 at Evansville.  A cold front over southwest Indiana was preceded by hot and humid southwest winds.

Rainfall totals in July reached historic levels again, only this time in central and southern Indiana. For the state, July 2015 was the 7th wettest July of record and the wettest since the record wet July of 1992. JulyÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩs rainfall prolonged the widespread river flooding that began in June and caused higher flooding in southern Indiana. Flooding along the Wabash River in western Indiana that began in mid June continued through most of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding continued along the White River from June through most of July. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. State Route 257 was flooded. Numerous Pike County roads were flooded, including County Roads 750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. West of State Route 57, County Roads 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W were flooded. Low agricultural lands and low oil fields were inundated. Because it was agricultural season, significant crop damage occurred. River cabins were isolated by high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired by late afternoon along a stalled baroclinic zone. Moderate instability and shear was sufficient for large hail and a few reports of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and powerlines down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Residents and local emergency management report water over the road on Highway 358 in several spots due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-1 tornado, with winds estimated at 90 mph, briefly touched down near the intersection of Southeastern and Irvington Avenues. Significant garage damage occurred to two homes and one automobile was stacked on top of another. Numerous trees were downed as well. A power pole was downed as well as a gazebo that was picked up and tossed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Wabash River. At the Mount Carmel river gage, the river crested at 25.8 feet on the 29th. Flood stage is 19 feet. Extensive lowland flooding occurred. Numerous local river roads were flooded. Some mobile homes were moved out of the flood plain. Access to local camp sites and river cabins was blocked, but there was minimal impact to commercial activities. Some nearby oil fields were inaccessible.  The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. High water affected any residents in Pottsville river cabins. A few streets were flooded and impassable. Oil stripped fields were flooded. Flood gates were installed at Hazleton. A softball field was underwater. The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of 1.5 inch diameter hail was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of 3/4 inch diameter hail was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of 1 inch diameter hail was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported trees down in the city of Austin.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An approaching weather system from the Upper Midwest and lower Great Lakes combined with the moderately moist and unstable air mass during the early evening hours. This produced localized severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report of trees down due to severe thunderstorm winds was received by the public.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large trees were downed in northeastern Hamilton County, from Cicero to Atlanta and eastward, due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at the Indianapolis Executive Airport measured a 70 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Corn and trees were damaged on Paragon Road near the White River due to strong thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down in this location due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were knocked down in a subdivision near the intersection of Franklin and Southport Roads due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. A trampoline was blown over causing some minor damage to a house and a few vehicles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was flowing over a roadway near Meridian Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The westbound lane of Highway 38 was underwater about half a mile west of Highway 13. Several inches of flowing water is also going over some driveways.  Heavy thunderstorm rainfall was the cause of the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Washington Street Bridge was closed due to flooding from thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Beginning on the 7th, numerous weather systems brought seemingly unending rains and at times torrential downpours to various portions of the state. The first heavy rains of the month occurred in portions of east central Illinois in addition to west central and northwest Indiana.  Rainfall of 2 to nearly 6 inches on the 7th caused flooding across portions of Warren, Fountain, and Vermillion counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatch reported high water along State Road 136, between Covington and Veedersburg, due to heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official relayed to the NWS that because of torrential rainfall, there were county roads flooded with high water flowing over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired by late afternoon along a stalled baroclinic zone. Moderate instability and shear was sufficient for large hail and a few reports of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several pictures received of Quarter sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired by late afternoon along a stalled baroclinic zone. Moderate instability and shear was sufficient for large hail and a few reports of damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Picture of half dollar sized hail received.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of a low pressure center which moved through the area. With moderate instability and shear, numerous severe storms developed with several reports of damaging winds. In addition, storm motion nearly parallel to the frontal boundary caused training storms and localized flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter sized hail. A few slightly larger than quarter sized. Wind gusts estimated 40 to 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms initiated along a stationary front across northern Indiana. Moderate instability and weak shear led to a few wet downbursts which caused isolated wind damage. The greater threat became flooding as rainfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour became common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down on powerlines on 300W near 300S.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers developed across northern Indiana and far southern Lower Michigan with one cell intensifying, eventually taking on a supercellular structure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Healthy 6 inch diameter tree branches down over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers developed across northern Indiana and far southern Lower Michigan with one cell intensifying, eventually taking on a supercellular structure.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Utility pole down near the intersection of Slusher Rd. and N. Webster Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stalled out frontal boundary draped across the Ohio Valley. The storms were very slow moving and produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The west fork of Four Mile Run came out of its banks and was flowing over Brookville Pike Road. A part of the road was washed away. In addition, trees were downed due to the flash flooding and a car was trapped in the water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stalled out frontal boundary draped across the Ohio Valley. The storms were very slow moving and produced locally heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water from earlier flash flooding covered parts of Brookville Pike Road through the night and into the early morning hours of July 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a morning complex of non-severe storms on June 7th, redeveloping storms in the early afternoon intensified just south of I-80 and slowly evolved southeastward through the night, producing heavy rainfall rates and at times severe straight-line winds.  Widespread rainfall of one and a half to four inches, with isolated totals higher fell across areas south of I-80. This produced flooding and flash flooding. Scattered reports of roads closed during Sunday mid-afternoon through evening were  received.  There were a couple reports of water rescues and stranded vehicles. The highest rainfall reports were 4.95 inches near Kouts, IN and 4.07 inches near Hebron, IN, both from CoCoRaHS volunteer observers.  There was video confirmation of two brief tornadoes in northern Jasper County, a few miles from the community of De Motte.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 tornado briefly touched down northwest of De Motte and was captured on video by trained spotters.  No damage occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ponding and water was running over county roadways due to heavy rainfall. Flooding was up to a foot and a half deep at the intersections of Toll Gate Road and 231st Street and Morse Landing Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: RTV6 reported that a Noblesville man and a teenage girl were killed in a one-car crash after encountering flooding on a Hamilton County road early Saturday morning. The man, 39, was driving with three juveniles on Promise Road north of 181st Street just before 12:30 AM EDT. The high water caused his car to go off the road and strike a mailbox and utility pole, officials with the Hamilton County SheriffÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩs Office said. He was taken to Riverview Hospital where he died of his injuries. One of the passengers was a 16-year-old girl who was in the back seat of the car. She also died of her injuries. The other two juvenile passengers were taken to a Fishers hospital with minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Kentucky state official indicated that because of torrential rainfall, there was high water flowing over Route 211. The report also indicated that other locations around town were experiencing high water and flooding issues.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Line of storms developed in a weakly sheared environment. Isolated pockets of mainly tree damage where cores collapsed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Line of storms developed in a weakly sheared environment. Isolated pockets of mainly tree damage where cores collapsed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines down. Trees estimated 8 to 12 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Line of storms developed in a weakly sheared environment. Isolated pockets of mainly tree damage where cores collapsed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limb down on 200S at US-33.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Line of storms developed in a weakly sheared environment. Isolated pockets of mainly tree damage where cores collapsed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downed utility pole.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a surface low over the upper Mississippi River valley and strong southerly flow from the Gulf to the Great Lakes, a weak trough and associated frontal boundary moved into a low CAPE, high shear environment. This favored development of several clusters of thunderstorms. The stronger convection merged into small, fast moving bow segments that produced sporadic wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a few trees were blown down near State Road 26 between County Roads 700 and 800 East. Roof panels of a barn were also damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into a weakly unstable environment, producing scattered thunderstorms. Pockets of strong wind aloft mixed down but struggled to reach severe levels. One storm took on super-cellular characteristics in the Fort Wayne area, but produced little more than very heavy rain and marginally severe hail.

A cold front moved into a weakly unstable environment, producing scattered thunderstorms. Pockets of strong wind aloft mixed down but struggled to reach severe levels. One storm took on super-cellular characteristics in the Fort Wayne area, but produced little more than very heavy rain and marginally severe hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported dime size hail in the Pleasant Mills area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The northbound lane of State Route 13, one mile north of Interstate 69, was impassable due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Anderson Fire Department worked two water rescues in the area of 8th Street and Raible Avenue due to flash flooding caused by heavy thunderstorm rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms pushed northeast into west-central and southwest Indiana during the evening hours of May the 15th. These storms produced severe winds as they moved northeast into southwest and central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was observed at the Channel 2 location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread river flooding occurred as a result of several heavy rain events in June. The remnants of Tropical Storm Bill on the 19th were responsible for widespread heavy rain that drove the smaller rivers above flood stage. Flooding of the White and Wabash Rivers was due to excessive rainfall in the upper portions of both river basins. Both Illinois and Indiana recorded their wettest Junes on record. June was also in the top five wettest months on record for both states.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. Low-lying woods and fields near the river were inundated. State Route 257 was flooded. Numerous Pike County roads were flooded, including County Roads 750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. West of State Route 57, County Roads 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W were flooded. Low agricultural lands and low oil fields were inundated. The flooding continued into July.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Line of storms developed in a weakly sheared environment. Isolated pockets of mainly tree damage where cores collapsed.
