EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer north of Bright measured 1.5 inches of snow, as did the observer 4 miles west of Aurora. The observer 3 miles west-northwest of Lawrenceburg measured 1.3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted northeast through the region during the early morning hours. Heavy snow fell from Brookville northward with a mix of rain and snow significantly cutting totals south of the I-74 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 4 miles south-southeast of Aurora measured a half inch of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm produced 4 to 9 inches of snow across southwest Indiana. Snowfall amounts generally increased from north to south, ranging from about 5 inches along the White River to 8 or 9 inches along the Ohio River. Rain gradually changed over to snow during the late morning and afternoon. A few hours of sleet and freezing rain occurred during the transition from rain to snow. Roads quickly became very slick and hazardous. Up to one-half inch of sleet accumulated, followed by snow. The snow fell heavily during the evening, accumulating at the rate of one-and-one-half inches per hour and reducing visibility below one-half mile. Specific snowfall reports included: 8.5 inches at Rockport (Spencer County), 8 inches at Mount Vernon (Posey County) and at Evansville, 7.5 inches at Chrisney (Spencer County), and 7 inches at Petersburg (Pike County). Four inches was reported at Francisco (Gibson County). North winds gusted up to 25 mph, causing some drifting of the snow. In Posey County, Interstate 64 eastbound was shut down after an accident involving a snow plow and a semi. Schools were closed for the remainder of the week in most counties. The 8.5 inches of snow at Evansville was the fourth biggest March snowstorm on record at that location. The March record was set in 1960, when 10.9 inches fell early in the month. Some of the coldest air ever recorded in the month of March invaded southwest Indiana the day after the snowstorm, hampering snow removal efforts. The low temperature was zero at Evansville on March 6. This was only the fifth time a temperature of zero or below had been recorded in the month of March. In the wake of a strong cold front that passed through on the night of the 3rd, an arctic high pressure center moved southeast into the central Plains. A deep 500 mb trough progressed slowly eastward from the Rockies across the Plains. This trough was responsible for a sustained period of moist southwest flow aloft. The relatively moist air overrunning cold air near the surface set the stage for widespread moderate to heavy snow.

A winter storm produced 4 to 9 inches of snow across southwest Indiana. Snowfall amounts generally increased from north to south, ranging from about 5 inches along the White River to 8 or 9 inches along the Ohio River. Rain gradually changed over to snow during the late morning and afternoon. A few hours of sleet and freezing rain occurred during the transition from rain to snow. Roads quickly became very slick and hazardous. Up to one-half inch of sleet accumulated, followed by snow. The snow fell heavily during the evening, accumulating at the rate of one-and-one-half inches per hour and reducing visibility below one-half mile. Specific snowfall reports included: 8.5 inches at Rockport (Spencer County), 8 inches at Mount Vernon (Posey County) and at Evansville, 7.5 inches at Chrisney (Spencer County), and 7 inches at Petersburg (Pike County). Four inches was reported at Francisco (Gibson County). North winds gusted up to 25 mph, causing some drifting of the snow. In Posey County, Interstate 64 eastbound was shut down after an accident involving a snow plow and a semi. Schools were closed for the remainder of the week in most counties. The 8.5 inches of snow at Evansville was the fourth biggest March snowstorm on record at that location. The March record was set in 1960, when 10.9 inches fell early in the month. Some of the coldest air ever recorded in the month of March invaded southwest Indiana the day after the snowstorm, hampering snow removal efforts. The low temperature was zero at Evansville on March 6. This was only the fifth time a temperature of zero or below had been recorded in the month of March. In the wake of a strong cold front that passed through on the night of the 3rd, an arctic high pressure center moved southeast into the central Plains. A deep 500 mb trough progressed slowly eastward from the Rockies across the Plains. This trough was responsible for a sustained period of moist southwest flow aloft. The relatively moist air overrunning cold air near the surface set the stage for widespread moderate to heavy snow.

Deepening low pressure tracking east through the northern Ohio Valley brought a prolonged period of moderate to heavy snow to the region February 1st into early February 2nd. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 12 and 17 inches north of the US 24 corridor, with lesser amounts to the south as rain mixed in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 10 and 14 inches, heaviest across northwest portions of the county. Wind gusts of 20 to 25 mph, combined with the falling snow, created reduced visibilities and blowing snow. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. There were also reports of road closures in rural areas as unplowed roads became impassible. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 11 and 15 inches, heaviest across northern portions of the county. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving across the southern U.S. brought accumulating snow to the southern half of central Indiana on February 16th. Some areas received around 8 inches of snow. Higher amounts were received in Kentucky with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 7.1 inches was observed southeast of Odon. Since the 16th was Presidents' Day, schools were not in session. Roads were reported to be slick. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy snowfall was pushing southeast through central Indiana on the afternoon of the 4th of February. A 79-year-old Rossville man left a store in Clinton County and it is thought that he hit a patch of heavier snowfall, left the road on Indiana 39/U.S. Highway 421, traveled down the berm, and entered Wildcat Creek where he made it out of his truck but drowned before reaching the creek's bank.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just north of Clinton County Road 200 North, a 79-year-old Rossville man and his truck left the east side of the road, traveled down the berm, and entered the creek. The man made it out of the truck, but was unable to get to the bank.||He had left home about 2 p.m. on February 4th to run to a store in Frankfort. Clinton County sheriffÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩs investigators said someone remembered seeing the man in a store about 3:15 p.m. That was about the time the snow squall started blowing through the area.||ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩEverything is leaning to a motor vehicle crash,ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ the Clinton County sheriff said.||The snow was so heavy and visibility was so poor in that area on February 4th that a construction crew working north of the creek pulled their trucks and equipment off the road to avoid any mishaps. It is sometime during this snow squall that the Rossville man likely was traveling north on Indiana 39/U.S. Highway 421.||This information was obtained from the Lafayette Journal and Courier online.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor to moderate flooding occurred along the Lower Wabash River and its tributaries. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. These events were on the 9th and 10th, and on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a rather extended flooding event in the Wabash River basin. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally minor to moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the White River. At the Petersburg river gage, the river crested at 23.62 feet on the 17th. Flood stage is 16 feet. Extensive flooding affected agricultural and rural residential areas. Several rural county roads were flooded. Several small oil fields were inaccessible. High water isolated some river cabins. State Road 257 south of Washington completely flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along most of the Ohio River, with pockets of only minor flooding. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a major winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. On the 9th and 10th, one to two inches of rain fell, followed by two to four more inches on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a prolonged flooding event on the Ohio River. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred on the Ohio River. At the Newburgh river gage, the river crested at 48.07 feet on the 17th. Flood stage is 38 feet. Floodwaters approached or covered Indiana Route 66 about one mile downriver from the Newburgh dam. Highway 662 was flooded near the old lock and dam. Some low-lying agricultural land was flooded. The crest of 48.07 feet was the tenth highest on record for Newburgh, and it was a foot below the April, 2011 flood crest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor to moderate flooding occurred along the Lower Wabash River and its tributaries. A heavy rainfall event on March 3 was followed by a winter storm on March 4 into early March 5. Two more heavy rainfall events occurred in quick succession. These events were on the 9th and 10th, and on the 13th and 14th. The combined effect of all these rain and snow events was a rather extended flooding event in the Wabash River basin. Since the precipitation was spread out over a 10-day period, the magnitude of the flooding was generally minor to moderate instead of major.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the Wabash River. At the Mount Carmel river gage, the river crested at 24.78 feet on the 19th. Flood stage is 19 feet. Extensive lowland flooding occurred. Access to local camp sites was blocked, but there was minimal impact to commercial activities. Several local roads were impassable. All oil field production ceased with the exception of pumping units on substructures. Access to these was by boat only. Farmers moved livestock to higher ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Low-lying fields and woodlands near the river were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Most river bottomland was inundated. Farmers moved livestock and equipment to higher ground. Basements along the riverfront began to fill. Flooding of Pigeon Creek, which runs along the east side of Evansville, was caused by backwater from the Ohio River. Some county roads were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Wabash River. Low-lying fields and woodlands near the river were inundated. Some stripper oil wells began to flood.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the Wabash River. At the New Harmony river gage, the river crested at 18.34 feet on the 20th. Flood stage is 15 feet. There was minor flooding of low-lying fields and bottomlands.

Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 6 and 9 inches, heaviest across northern portions of the county. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Rain mixed in with the snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 1st which limited snow accumulations somewhat. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 5 and 8 inches, heaviest across northern portions of the county. Wind gusts of 15 to 25 mph, combined with the falling snow, created reduced visibilities and blowing snow. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Farmland and some county roads were flooded in places southwest and west of Mount Vernon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River. There was considerable flooding of bottomland woods and fields. A number of county roads were flooded, including  |750N, 600N, and 1000E east of State Route 57. Flooded roads west of State Route  57 included 250W, 400W, 675N, 700N, 1000W, 900W, 700W, and 775W. Flooding affected low agricultural lands and low oil fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Wabash River. A few local river roads were closed by high water. All oil field production ceased with the exception of pumping units on substructures. Farmers moved livestock to higher ground. Many river cabins became inaccessible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure tracking east through the northern Ohio Valley brought a prolonged period of moderate to heavy snow to the region February 1st into early February 2nd. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 12 and 17 inches north of the US 24 corridor, with lesser amounts to the south as rain mixed in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Rain mixed in with the snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 1st which limited snow accumulations somewhat. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged from near 4 inches in far southern portions of the county to as much as 10 inches in far northern Miami County. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 inches was observed in the Vernon area. Roads were reported to be slick. Since the 16th was Presidents' Day, schools were not in session. Some schools had delays the following day. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the White River. The flooding was in response to heavy rainfall on the 3rd caused by a surface low pressure system that moved northward from the western Gulf coast. The low brought widespread heavy rainfall averaging from one to three inches, with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River near Hazleton. Floodwaters covered low ground, inundating low-lying oil fields. A couple of low rural roads were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow behind a departing arctic front pulled a significant amount of moisture over the Ohio Valley Friday night, February 20th into Saturday the 21st. As the low level jet encountered a mid level disturbance, snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were noted over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EMA in Centerville measured 5 inches of snow. A social media post from Hagerstown measured 4.5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow behind a departing arctic front pulled a significant amount of moisture over the Ohio Valley Friday night, February 20th into Saturday the 21st. As the low level jet encountered a mid level disturbance, snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were noted over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer northeast of Alpine measured 2.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow behind a departing arctic front pulled a significant amount of moisture over the Ohio Valley Friday night, February 20th into Saturday the 21st. As the low level jet encountered a mid level disturbance, snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were noted over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A social media post from Liberty measured 4 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Ohio, Wabash, White, and Patoka Rivers rose back above flood stage after a series of heavy rainfall events in late March and early April. Showers and thunderstorms were frequent during the first few days of the month ahead of a surface cold front. A warm front brought more rain on the 7th. Rainfall totals averaged one to three inches during the first few days of the month, and another inch or so fell with the warm front.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along the Patoka River. At the river gage near Princeton, the river crested at 22.57 feet on the 10th. Flood stage is 18 feet. Many county roads were closed in the vicinity of the river. The flooding affected areas of farmland. Seasonal camping trailers closest to the river were flooded or moved to higher ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure tracking east through the northern Ohio Valley brought a prolonged period of moderate to heavy snow to the region February 1st into early February 2nd. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 12 and 17 inches north of the US 24 corridor, with lesser amounts to the south as rain mixed in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Rain mixed in with the snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 1st which limited snow accumulations somewhat. Total snow accumulations generally ranged from near 4 inches in far southern portions of the county to as much as 9 inches in far northern Wells County. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads. The heavy, wet, nature of the snow also led to sporadic power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred on the White River. The flooding was in response to heavy rainfall on the 3rd caused by a surface low pressure system that moved northward from the western Gulf coast. The low brought widespread heavy rainfall averaging from one to three inches, with isolated higher amounts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the White River near Petersburg. Lowland flooding affected a number of rural county roads. Flooding affected low agricultural lands and low oil fields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure tracking east through the northern Ohio Valley brought a prolonged period of moderate to heavy snow to the region February 1st into early February 2nd. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 12 and 17 inches north of the US 24 corridor, with lesser amounts to the south as rain mixed in.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light snow developed during the late evening hours of January 31st and became heavy at times February 1st into early February 2nd. Rain mixed in with the snow during the morning and early afternoon hours of February 1st which limited snow accumulations somewhat. Total snow accumulations generally ranged from near 3 inches in far southern portions of the county to as much as 8 inches in far northern Wells County. Numerous events were cancelled across the region, along with reports of slide-offs and accidents due to snow covered and slick roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band produced a narrow band of heavy snow and blowing snow across far northwest Indiana on February 12th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 2 and 8 inches within this band.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and blowing snow accompanied an intense lake effect snow band on February 12th, mainly during the late morning and afternoon hours across northeast portions of La Porte County. A spotter reported 7 inches of accumulation 3 miles east of Rolling Prairie. Areas farther west and south across the county received less snow accumulation. The falling snow combined with wind gusts to 30 mph created near whiteout conditions and hazardous travel. There were reports of a few accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front which pushed across the region during the morning hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 68 mph instantaneous gust was recorded on a personal weather station. The average gust was 48 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.

A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A microburst containing winds estimated near 85 mph tracked north and northeast of Boonville. More than a dozen homes and other structures lost shingles or pieces of siding. Dozens of trees were uprooted. Many tree limbs were blown down. The microburst was about one mile wide on average.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 1.40 inches was measured in 30 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought hazardous conditions to southwest Indiana. The precipitation type was primarily freezing rain. Some sleet and snow was reported at the onset. Around one-quarter inch of ice glazed trees and power lines, on top of one-quarter to one-half inch of sleet. Roads became ice-covered and very hazardous. Numerous vehicle crashes and slide-offs occurred. Isolated power outages were reported due to tree limbs on power lines. A utility company estimated outages totaled about 500 customers. Downed tree limbs damaged vehicles at the campus of Southern Indiana University. Several east-to-west bands of light to locally moderate precipitation advanced slowly northward in response to the arrival of warm, moist air in the low levels. Strengthening of a southerly low level jet occurred ahead of a 500 mb shortwave impulse emerging out of the central Plains. Convective enhancement of precipitation rates was observed. After the precipitation changed to rain, the combination of snowmelt and rainfall produced localized street flooding. Most of the street flooding was in urban areas, such as Evansville.

A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported that large trees fell on Graham Rd due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jasper Middle School mesonet weather observation measured a gust of 52 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media relayed that wind gusts estimated to be between 65 and 70 mph occurred.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two consecutive heavy rain events, combined with snowmelt from the March 4th storm, produced some localized flooding. On the 10th and 11th, widespread showers produced average rainfall amounts around one inch, with isolated places reporting near two inches. Between the 12th and 14th, a storm system developed in east Texas and phased with an upper-level trough moving east through the upper Mississippi Valley. Widespread moderate to heavy rain produced rain totals between 2 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The rain total on the 13th was 1.77 inches. Another 0.41 inches fell early on the 14th. The storm-total rainfall was 2.18 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mixed bag of wintry precipitation caused hazardous travel conditions north of Interstate 64. Across most of Gibson and Pike Counties, the precipitation was in the form of light snow, sleet, and freezing drizzle. Along the White River, one inch of new snow was reported at Hazleton. To the south, amounts were generally one-tenth inch or less along Interstate 64. Little if any wintry precipitation occurred in the counties bordering the Ohio River. The precipitation was caused by a surge of warmer air aloft moving north across the region. The warmer air aloft moved over a shallow layer of cold air near the surface. As the depth of cold air decreased, the precipitation changed from sleet and freezing drizzle to liquid drizzle. This event continued into the first day of March.

An area of low pressure brought snow to central Indiana, starting the evening of February 28th and continuing into March 1st. Parts of central Indiana received up to 11 to 12.5 inches of snow during the event. The 11 inches of snow on the ground at Indianapolis on March 1st was the most snow on the ground so late in the year since February 29th, 1984, which also had 11 inches. Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 5:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 7 inches were reported in and around the Terre Haute area before ending around 3:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread dense fog, with visibilities reduced to as low as 20 feet, created hazardous driving conditions during the morning hours of March 11th. The fog was partially blamed for a 22 car accident that killed 2 people on I-65 in White County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog played havoc from the late evening hours of March 10th to shortly after sunrise on March 11th, contributing to several accidents and numerous school closings. This dense fog was a factor in 2 separate accidents, the first occurring around 10 pm local time on Interstate 65 near mile marker 188, with a second in the early morning hours of the 11th. A car and semi collided, resulting in the death of a passenger in the car. Other vehicles became involved in the accident with additional injuries reported. A second accident occurred in the same area, likely due to traffic stopping for the first accident, causing yet another fatality as well as several injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down just west of U.S. Highway 41 and then moved south of due east. Power poles were broken along U.S. Highway 41. At least three farm machinery sheds and garages were destroyed. Three grain bins were destroyed. Numerous other small structures were overturned or destroyed. One home had major structural damage, including an exterior wall pushed outward. The exterior wall was on the end of the house with an attached garage. Dozens of homes lost shingles or gutters. Many dozens of trees were uprooted or snapped. A semi was overturned at the Interstate 164 junction with State Route 57. Peak winds were estimated near 110 mph. The average path width was 325 yards. The majority of damage occurred in Vanderburgh County. This tornado continued into Warrick County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported multiple trees fell down along Highway 31 near Clark State Forest because of severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms moved eastward into southwest Indiana during the late evening hours. At the surface, a low pressure center over northwest Missouri deepened northeastward into southern Wisconsin. A cold front trailing south-southwest from the low strengthened and accelerated east across the Mid-Mississippi Valley and Ozarks to the Lower Ohio Valley. At mid levels, the storms were supported by a weak lead disturbance that crossed the Ozarks, headed northeast to the Ohio Valley. Ample west-southwesterly deep-layer wind shear (from 40 to 45 knots) existed for sustained severe storms. The degree of low-level forcing along the front resulted in an extensive, broken squall line with embedded bowing structures. A bowing structure moved through the Evansville airport area, producing a corridor of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds estimated near 70 mph caused damage at the Evansville Regional Airport. The three-mile long damage area began about two miles west of the airport and ended on the east side of the airport. The damage area was up to two-thirds of a mile wide. West of the airport, several sections of yard fencing and numerous tree limbs and small trees were blown down. The end roof section of a vinyl roof building was blown off. The covering of a nearby sign board was blown partially off. At the Evansville airport, a tarmac loading ramp was blown into the side of a commercial aircraft. The aircraft was dented, and the flight was cancelled. A utility light pole was blown over at the airport. A wind gust to 67 mph was measured by the automated observing system at the Evansville Regional Airport.

Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 7:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 7 to 8 inches were reported across the Kokomo and Greentown areas before ending around 3:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

Peak winds were estimated near 110 mph.

The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were down on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms moved eastward into southwest Indiana during the late evening hours. At the surface, a low pressure center over northwest Missouri deepened northeastward into southern Wisconsin. A cold front trailing south-southwest from the low strengthened and accelerated east across the Mid-Mississippi Valley and Ozarks to the Lower Ohio Valley. At mid levels, the storms were supported by a weak lead disturbance that crossed the Ozarks, headed northeast to the Ohio Valley. Ample west-southwesterly deep-layer wind shear (from 40 to 45 knots) existed for sustained severe storms. The degree of low-level forcing along the front resulted in an extensive, broken squall line with embedded bowing structures. A bowing structure moved through the Evansville airport area, producing a corridor of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A wind gust was measured to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of low pressure brought snow to central Indiana, starting the evening of February 28th and continuing into March 1st. Parts of central Indiana received up to 11 to 12.5 inches of snow during the event. The 11 inches of snow on the ground at Indianapolis on March 1st was the most snow on the ground so late in the year since February 29th, 1984, which also had 11 inches. Some counties north of the warned area accumulated 6 inches of snow after 12 hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall began around 7:00 PM EST on February 28th. Snowfall amounts of 5.5 to 6 inches were reported from the Shelbyville and Waldron areas before ending around 3:00 PM EST on March 1st.  No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water running over Highway 145 south of Birdseye.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 4 and 6 inches of rain quickly brought the Muscatatuck River at Deputy into flood. The river crested at 25.63 feet during the afternoon of April 3rd, then fell below flood stage later that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain brought the Blue River at Fredericksburg into flood. The river crested at 21.79 feet feet on April 3rd and then fell below flood stage early on April 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported trees uprooted and snapped due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado began along the eastern edge of Warrick County. Peak winds were estimated near 95 mph. Some trees were damaged. Most of the damage occurred during the Spencer County portion of the track. This tornado continued into Spencer County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few isolated damaging wind gusts occurred with bands of northeastward moving thunderstorms. Weak to moderate instability and deep, unidirectional southwesterly flow aloft helped to maintain the storms. A 500 mb shortwave trough over the Ozarks moved northeast to the vicinity of the Ohio and Mississippi River confluence by mid-afternoon. A weak surface low pressure center moved northeast from southeast Missouri into south central Illinois.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small child was killed when a tree limb landed on her. The incident occurred at an outdoor family reunion. The tree limb fell about 50 feet, striking a father and his daughter. The father was hospitalized with a broken neck and other injuries. The young girl died in the hospital a couple of days later. There were a couple of other downed tree limbs in the immediate area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: After a very wet and active weather pattern in March, little relief was observed in April across much of the lower Great Lakes and Ohio Valley. Repeated rounds of heavy rain, thunderstorms and occasional severe weather occurred in the Ohio River basin across Indiana, northern Kentucky and portions of Ohio. This resulted in a prolonged period of high water and flooding on the Ohio River, especially from Cannelton to Tell City.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rain both locally and well upstream brought the Ohio River at Cannelton to flood. The river crested at 42.3 feet on April 18th, then fell below flood stage on April 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management reported trees down around the Jasper area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a porch roof was damaged due to severe thunderstorm winds gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several ingredients came together to produce 10 to 15 inches of snowfall across northwest Indiana, with locally higher totals.  A deepening center of low pressure lifting from the Southern Plains through the Ohio Valley pulled rich moisture out of the tropical Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico and wrapped it into cold Arctic air.  Early in the event the relatively mild surface temperatures in the 30s kept snow-to-liquid ratios on the lower end of the spectrum, or close to 10-to-1.  As the event progressed and colder air spread into the region, the snow evolved from wet and heavy to very light and fluffy as ratios eventually increased to 30-to-1 or higher.  ||A tightening pressure gradient around the low center as it moved from central Illinois into central Indiana also supported strong and gusty northeast winds later Sunday afternoon into the evening, producing a period of blizzard to near blizzard conditions with gusts over 35 mph and visibilities around 1/4 mile or less in many locations.||Some of the highest snowfall reports include:  17.0 inches near Hobard (Lake); 16.0 inches near Valparaiso (Porter); 13.5 inches near De Motte (Jasper); and 10.0 inches in Morocco (Newton).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mixed bag of wintry precipitation caused hazardous travel conditions north of Interstate 64. Across most of Gibson and Pike Counties, the precipitation was in the form of light snow, sleet, and freezing drizzle. Along the White River, one inch of new snow was reported at Hazleton. To the south, amounts were generally one-tenth inch or less along Interstate 64. Little if any wintry precipitation occurred in the counties bordering the Ohio River. The precipitation was caused by a surge of warmer air aloft moving north across the region. The warmer air aloft moved over a shallow layer of cold air near the surface. As the depth of cold air decreased, the precipitation changed from sleet and freezing drizzle to liquid drizzle. This event continued into the first day of March.

Thunderstorms developed along a northward moving warm front, with a few producing marginally severe hail.

Thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity as a cold front moved eastward across the Lower Ohio Valley. Daytime heating and destabilization resulted in mixed-layer cape values approaching 1000 j/kg. Locally heavy rainfall occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported 2.32 inches since the previous night. Of that total, 0.78 inch came in 20 minutes in the early afternoon storms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stalled frontal boundary across the area brought several rounds of showers and thunderstorms to the lower Ohio Valley April 2nd and 3rd. Training thunderstorms during the early morning hours of April 3rd resulted in flash flooding across portions of southern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported high water on Interstate 64 that forced semi trailers off the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm brought hazardous conditions to southwest Indiana. The precipitation type was primarily freezing rain. Some sleet and snow was reported at the onset. Around one-quarter inch of ice glazed trees and power lines, on top of one-quarter to one-half inch of sleet. Roads became ice-covered and very hazardous. Numerous vehicle crashes and slide-offs occurred. Isolated power outages were reported due to tree limbs on power lines. A utility company estimated outages totaled about 500 customers. Downed tree limbs damaged vehicles at the campus of Southern Indiana University. Several east-to-west bands of light to locally moderate precipitation advanced slowly northward in response to the arrival of warm, moist air in the low levels. Strengthening of a southerly low level jet occurred ahead of a 500 mb shortwave impulse emerging out of the central Plains. Convective enhancement of precipitation rates was observed. After the precipitation changed to rain, the combination of snowmelt and rainfall produced localized street flooding. Most of the street flooding was in urban areas, such as Evansville.

Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.

Snow and strong winds created near blizzard conditions at times on February 14th along and behind a strong arctic front. Snow amounts generally ranged between 1 and 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 45 mph and snow squalls enhanced by Lake Michigan created near whiteout conditions at times on February 14th. Visibilities were reduced to less than 100 feet in heavier snow showers, with total snow accumulations generally ranging between 1 and 3 inches. This created difficult driving conditions with some roads becoming impassible due to significant blowing and drifting snow. Several multi-vehicle accidents were reported across the region due to reduced visibilities and slick roads.

An arctic cold front crossed the region during the afternoon. It produced a weak surface low pressure center that tracked east along the Ohio River. Accumulating snow of 1 to 3 inches were found throughout the region, with some higher readings grouped along or near the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report from Vevay showed that 4 inches of snow had fallen.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Centerville received an inch of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the region in advance of a warm front late in the evening on February 28th and continued into the early afternoon on March 1st. Snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches and reduced visibilities made travel difficult on March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated to between 5 and 7 inches late February 28th through the early afternoon on March 1st. There was a report of 6.0 inches of total snow accumulation in Mexico. There were a few minor accidents reported across the region due to snow covered roads and reduced visibilities, especially during the morning hours of March 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills to 20 below zero and accumulating lake effect snow showers affected far north-central Indiana behind an arctic cold front February 18th into February 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers created hazardous driving conditions behind an arctic front February 18th into February 19th. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region thanks to reduced visibilities and snow covered roads. Total snow accumulations were highly variable across the county, generally ranging between 2 and 8 inches. South Bend received 8.0 inches of total snow accumulation. Wind chills dropped to between 10 below and 20 below zero during this time which led to numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front crossed the area and produced snow squalls. Whiteout conditions with wind gusting to between 40 and 60 mph created extremely hazardous driving conditions. Numerous accidents and road closures were noted across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous snow squalls and strong wind gusts negatively impacted the region with whiteout conditions at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front crossed the area and produced snow squalls. Whiteout conditions with wind gusting to between 40 and 60 mph created extremely hazardous driving conditions. Numerous accidents and road closures were noted across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rain fell over ground that was saturated from a combination of snowmelt and a heavy rainstorm in late February. The heavy rain was caused by a slow-moving cold front that crossed the Lower Ohio Valley during the evening of the 3rd. Ahead of a large 500 mb trough over the Rockies, very moist southwest flow aloft sustained an extensive area of moderate to heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of the Lloyd Expressway were flooded in the typical spots that are poorly drained.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving MCS moved through the Ohio Valley during the morning of April 8th.

Southerly flow behind a departing arctic front pulled a significant amount of moisture over the Ohio Valley Friday night, February 20th into Saturday the 21st. As the low level jet encountered a mid level disturbance, snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were noted over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Brookville measured 5.5 inches of snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report from the Batesville area showed that 6.5 inches of snow had fallen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly flow behind a departing arctic front pulled a significant amount of moisture over the Ohio Valley Friday night, February 20th into Saturday the 21st. As the low level jet encountered a mid level disturbance, snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were noted over much of the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report from the St. Leon area showed that 7.5 inches of snow had fallen. A public report in Lawrenceburg stated that 7 inches had fallen there.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of light freezing rain in advance of an approaching warm front created slick roadways in time for the morning commute on March 3rd. Ice accretions of around a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of Light freezing rain with temperatures in the mid to upper 20s created slick spots on area roads during the morning hours of March 3rd. These icy conditions led to numerous school closings and minor accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and strong winds created near blizzard conditions at times on February 14th along and behind a strong arctic front. Snow amounts generally ranged between 1 and 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 45 mph and snow squalls enhanced by Lake Michigan created near whiteout conditions at times on February 14th. Visibilities were reduced to less than 100 feet in heavier snow showers, with total snow accumulations generally ranging between 1 and 3 inches. This created difficult driving conditions with some roads becoming impassible due to significant blowing and drifting snow. Several multi-vehicle accidents were reported across the region due to reduced visibilities and slick roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving MCS moved through the Ohio Valley during the morning of April 8th.
A fast moving MCS moved through the Ohio Valley during the morning of April 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed in the Richmond area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow and strong winds created near blizzard conditions at times on February 14th along and behind a strong arctic front. Snow amounts generally ranged between 1 and 3 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 45 mph and snow squalls along and behind an arctic front created near whiteout conditions at times on February 14th. Visibilities were reduced to less than 200 feet in heavier snow showers, with total snow accumulations generally ranging between 1 and 3 inches. Several multi-vehicle accidents were reported across the region due to reduced visibilities and slick roads, including a crash involving up to 20 vehicles in the southbound lane of I-69 near the DeKalb and Steuben County line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the region in advance of a warm front late in the evening on February 28th and continued into the early afternoon on March 1st. Snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches and reduced visibilities made travel difficult on March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated to between 5 and 7 inches late February 28th through the early afternoon on March 1st. There were a few minor accidents reported across the region due to snow covered roads and reduced visibilities, especially during the morning hours of March 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the region in advance of a warm front late in the evening on February 28th and continued into the early afternoon on March 1st. Snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches and reduced visibilities made travel difficult on March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated to between 4 and 5 inches late February 28th through the early afternoon on March 1st. There was a report of 4.0 inches of total snow accumulation in Fort Wayne. There were a few minor accidents reported across the region due to snow covered roads and reduced visibilities, especially during the morning hours of March 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This winter weather event continued from the last day of February. A mixed bag of wintry precipitation caused hazardous travel conditions north of Interstate 64. Across most of Gibson and Pike Counties, the precipitation was in the form of light snow, sleet, and freezing drizzle. Along the White River, one inch of new snow was reported at Hazleton. To the south, amounts were generally one-tenth inch or less along Interstate 64. Little if any wintry precipitation occurred in the counties bordering the Ohio River. The precipitation was caused by a surge of warmer air aloft moving north across the region. The warmer air aloft moved over a shallow layer of cold air near the surface. As the depth of cold air decreased, the precipitation changed from sleet and freezing drizzle to liquid drizzle.

Several multi-vehicle accidents were reported across the region due to reduced visibilities and slick roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills to 20 below zero and accumulating lake effect snow showers affected far north-central Indiana behind an arctic cold front February 18th into February 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers created hazardous driving conditions behind an arctic front February 18th into February 19th. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region thanks to reduced visibilities and snow covered roads. Total snow accumulations were highly variable across the county, ranging from a trace in southwest La Porte county to between 2 and 4 inches in far northeast La Porte County. Wind chills dropped to between 10 below and 20 below zero during this time which led to numerous school delays and closings. A 79 year old LaPorte woman died from exposure to the cold on February 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the region and produced an inch or two of snow across the Ohio Valley as it passed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer located 2 miles north of Bright measured an inch of snow. Another observer 3 miles west-northwest of Lawrenceburg also measured an inch.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the region and produced an inch or two of snow across the Ohio Valley as it passed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A report from Vevay indicated that 2 inches of snow had fallen.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic cold front crossed the region during the afternoon. It produced a weak surface low pressure center that tracked east along the Ohio River. Accumulating snow of 1 to 3 inches were found throughout the region, with some higher readings grouped along or near the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Both the observer located 2 miles north of Bright and a spotter near Aurora measured 2.8 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Dangerous wind chills to 20 below zero and accumulating lake effect snow showers affected far north-central Indiana behind an arctic cold front February 18th into February 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow showers created hazardous driving conditions behind an arctic front February 18th into February 19th. There were reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region thanks to reduced visibilities and snow covered roads. Total snow accumulations were highly variable across the county, generally ranging from 1 to 2 inches across southern and eastern portions of the county to as much as 5 inches in far northwest Elkhart County. Wind chills dropped to between 10 below and 20 below zero during this time which led to numerous school delays and closings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 5th through January 10th featured a prolonged period of very cold weather and sub-zero wind chills. The most extreme and dangerous push of this arctic air occurred on January 8th when wind chills dropped to between 20 below zero and 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 8th ranged between 20 below zero and 30 below zero. This dangerous cold led to numerous school closings and delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Connersville measured 1.2 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The cooperative observer in Brookville measured 3 inches of snow, as did a spotter on the northwest side of town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the region and produced an inch or two of snow across the Ohio Valley as it passed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager in Centerville measured an inch of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front crossed the region and produced an inch or two of snow across the Ohio Valley as it passed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer located 4 miles northeast of Osgood measured 2 inches of snow. Another observer in Batesville measured 0.9 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought accumulating snow to central Indiana on February 21st, starting in the early morning hours and continuing into the early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally from 3 to 7 inches. Across far southern portions of central Indiana, a mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow fell, with overall lower snow amounts. During the mid to late afternoon, skies became partly cloudy and allowed temperatures to climb into the 30s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5.5 inches was observed in Blanford. No other impacts were reported.

During the mid to late afternoon, skies became partly cloudy and allowed temperatures to climb into the 30s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The CoCoRaHS observer located 6 miles south-southeast of Moore's Hill measured 4.2 inches of snow. A public report of 4.1 inches came from near Aurora, and the other CoCoRaHS observers located 3 miles west-northwest of Lawrenceburg and 4 miles west of Aurora both measured 4 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Cross Plains, 4.5 inches of snow fell. The CoCoRaHS observer near Batesville measured 4 inches of snow. Another CoCoRaHS observer located 4 miles northeast of Osgood measured 3 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, it is estimated that 4 to 4.5 inches of snow fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong surface low pressure system tracked from the southern plains to the gulf states on Monday, February 16th. A northward push of the system clipped the southern Ohio Valley, and significant snow fell along and particularly south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Based on surrounding observations, it is estimated that 5 to 7 inches of snow fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front changed an area of moderate rain to heavy snow as it crossed from northwest to southeast Wednesday afternoon and overnight. An upper level wave of energy translated east along the front and increased snowfall rates to 1 to 2 inches per hour over much of the region along and south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer located 4 miles northeast of Osgood measured 2.5 inches of snow. Another observer located north of Batesville measured 1.4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front changed an area of moderate rain to heavy snow as it crossed from northwest to southeast Wednesday afternoon and overnight. An upper level wave of energy translated east along the front and increased snowfall rates to 1 to 2 inches per hour over much of the region along and south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer located  3 miles west-northwest of Lawrenceburg measured 3.1 inches of snow. Another observer located 4 miles west of Aurora measured 3 inches. A third observer located 2 miles north of Bright measured 1.8 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought accumulating snow to central Indiana on February 21st, starting in the early morning hours and continuing into the early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally from 3 to 7 inches. Across far southern portions of central Indiana, a mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow fell, with overall lower snow amounts. During the mid to late afternoon, skies became partly cloudy and allowed temperatures to climb into the 30s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5.5 to 7 inches was observed in and around the Avon and Danville areas. No other impacts were reported.

During the mid to late afternoon, skies became partly cloudy and allowed temperatures to climb into the 30s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6.2 inches was observed on the southeast side of Indianapolis. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some trees were reported down with an estimated thunderstorm wind gust of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were downed on to power lines in and around Martinsville due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts and saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple power poles were downed at the intersection of County Road 400 West and State Route 144 due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A grain silo was downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front changed an area of moderate rain to heavy snow as it crossed from northwest to southeast Wednesday afternoon and overnight. An upper level wave of energy translated east along the front and increased snowfall rates to 1 to 2 inches per hour over much of the region along and south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 center located 4 miles east of Aberdeen measured 6.5 inches of snow, and also reported 3.5 inches of snow fell in Rising Sun. A CoCoRaHS observer located 4 miles south-southeast of Aurora also measured 3.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front changed an area of moderate rain to heavy snow as it crossed from northwest to southeast Wednesday afternoon and overnight. An upper level wave of energy translated east along the front and increased snowfall rates to 1 to 2 inches per hour over much of the region along and south of the Ohio River.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EMA measured 9 inches of snow in Vevay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought accumulating snow to central Indiana on February 21st, starting in the early morning hours and continuing into the early afternoon. Snowfall amounts were generally from 3 to 7 inches. Across far southern portions of central Indiana, a mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow fell, with overall lower snow amounts. During the mid to late afternoon, skies became partly cloudy and allowed temperatures to climb into the 30s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 7 inches was observed in New Whiteland. No other impacts were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity as a cold front moved eastward across the Lower Ohio Valley. Daytime heating and destabilization resulted in mixed-layer cape values approaching 1000 j/kg. Locally heavy rainfall occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 2.6 inches during the past 12 hours. Of that total, one inch fell in a 30-minute period in the early afternoon storms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5.5 to 6 inches was observed in portions of the county. No other impacts were reported.

Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was covering the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms moved over northwestern Indiana on the evening of May 5th with at least one thunderstorm producing nickel size hail.

Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A chimney was blown over onto a roof and shingles were torn off in large sections due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 63 mph thunderstorm wind gust was reported from KOVO.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a cold front during the evening of April 9th and then pushed across central Indiana into the early morning hours of April 10th. Some of the storms became severe, producing damaging winds. Heavy rain and small hail occurred with some storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets were flooded with 6 to 8 inches of water due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the region in advance of a warm front late in the evening on February 28th and continued into the early afternoon on March 1st. Snowfall totals of 4 to 8 inches and reduced visibilities made travel difficult on March 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated to between 7 and 8 inches late February 28th through the early afternoon on March 1st. There was a report of 7.8 inches of total snow accumulation in Marion. There were a few minor accidents reported across the region due to snow covered roads and reduced visibilities, especially during the morning hours of March 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 5th through January 10th featured a prolonged period of very cold weather and sub-zero wind chills. The most extreme and dangerous push of this arctic air occurred on January 8th when wind chills dropped to between 20 below zero and 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 8th ranged between 20 below zero and 30 below zero. This dangerous cold led to numerous school closings and delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: January 5th through January 10th featured a prolonged period of very cold weather and sub-zero wind chills. The most extreme and dangerous push of this arctic air occurred on January 8th when wind chills dropped to between 20 below zero and 30 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills during the morning and early afternoon hours of January 8th ranged between 20 below zero and 30 below zero. This dangerous cold led to numerous school closings and delays across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operator reported this observation to Emergency Management.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency Management received this report from a spotter near US Highway 52 and County Road 400 North.

Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime size hail reports were received via videos and pictures on Twitter from 7:39 PM to 7:44 PM. This occurred near Olio Road and 131st Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed south of a frontal boundary during the afternoon of May 4th. These storms produced hail and heavy rain from west to east across central portions of Indiana. Hail up to golf ball size was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of hail was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Patricia came ashore in Louisiana. Ahead of an eastward-moving cold front, abundant tropical moisture was drawn northward into the Lower Ohio Valley. Most locations received between 1 and 2 inches of rain, but there were some sites that reported between 3 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 3.61 inches of rain, mostly during the afternoon and evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The remnants of Tropical Storm Patricia came ashore in Louisiana. Ahead of an eastward-moving cold front, abundant tropical moisture was drawn northward into the Lower Ohio Valley. Most locations received between 1 and 2 inches of rain, but there were some sites that reported between 3 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured 3.50 inches of rain, mostly during the afternoon and evening. Street flooding was reported. Ditches were at bankfull.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread frost and sub-freezing temperatures brought an end to the growing season across southwest Indiana. Cold Canadian high pressure settled over the Lower Ohio Valley, creating ideal radiational cooling conditions. Lows ranged from the upper 20's in outlying rural areas to around 30 in the city of Evansville.
