Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported trees and some large limbs down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported roughly a half dozen trees uprooted in the same direction. A wall was removed from a chicken coop.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported trees and tree limbs down, with some into roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported sporadic trees being blown down onto the road between Otter Lake and Crooked Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported two trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported that a building, known as the Round Barn, sustained damage at the Fulton County museum. Review of the photos indicates that a microburst likely occurred in an open area with the wind traveling to a double barn door that was pushed in and the roof then compromised. Few if any other adjacent damage indicators were impacted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms dropped across northwestern Indiana producing severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerlines were blown down in Portage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms dropped across northwestern Indiana producing severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Powerlines were blown down across portions of Valparaiso.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe storms on the afternoon of the 3rd produced large hail across portions of Delaware and Randolph Counties.  Golf ball size hail occurred southeast of Muncie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail fell for 5 to 10 minutes and covered the ground in patches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across northern Wisconsin with a cold front sweeping into the region. An unstable atmosphere was in place with steep low level lapse rates and a strong elevated mixed layer.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe storms on the afternoon of the 3rd produced large hail across portions of Delaware and Randolph Counties.  Golf ball size hail occurred southeast of Muncie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was seen on Facebook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak disturbance moved into northern Indiana during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Roughly 1000 J/Kg of surface based CAPE was available with a very weak flow aloft (10 to 20 knots). Thunderstorms slowly developed across the area and given the weak flow moved very slowly. Isolated wind damage and flooding was reported from a few storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm remained over Lake Wawasee for nearly 90 minutes, dropping torrential rainfall. Rainfall totals peak out at just over 5 inches, on the northeast side of the lake. Flooding occurred on State Route 13, near the South Shore Golf Course, where high water signs had to be posted for several hours. Flooding was minimized across the area as a result of the majority of the rain likely falling into the lake. Rainfall amounts quickly diminished a few miles outside of this main area with the National Weather Service office picking up 1.86 inches of rain in the same amount of time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe storms on the afternoon of the 3rd produced large hail across portions of Delaware and Randolph Counties.  Golf ball size hail occurred southeast of Muncie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement out on a call observed the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Sunny skies ahead of a strong cold front allowed for the mixing of stronger winds aloft to the ground. While wind gusts only peaked out at between 30 and 40 mph, they were sufficient to cause damage to a tree in South Bend which fell onto several people in bleachers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree branch was blown down by gusty winds onto a bleacher at a soccer game in Studebaker Park. Five people of varying ages, including a ten month old girl were injured. The ten month old child died as a result of her injuries on August 5th. A ten year old child suffered severe head trauma with others suffering various cuts and bruises.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A compact storm system interacted with a warm and unstable airmass in the late afternoon and evening of April 7th to produce severe weather over portions of southern Indiana. In addition to a tornado in Perry County, wind damage and large hail occurred with the stronger storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported numerous flooded cars due to excessive heavy rainfall. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain fell across the county on top of very saturated ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mesoscale convective system moved east-southeast from southern Illinois into southwest Indiana. The complex transitioned from a continuous line of storms to a more discrete storm mode, with two distinct supercells. The supercell over southwest Indiana produced three tornadoes along its track across Vanderburgh, Warrick, and Spencer Counties. The storms encountered a moderately unstable air mass and sufficient deep-layer wind shear for storm organization. Mixed-layer capes around 1000 to 1500 j/kg were supported by temperatures in the upper 70's and dew points in the lower 60's. This instability, coupled with effective wind shear near 40 knots, supported supercell activity with tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree limbs were down. A trained spotter measured a wind gust to 67 mph before the wind equipment was ripped off its pole.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary surface boundary across the region combined with an upper level disturbance coming in from the west produced a round of scattered strong to severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana. The main hazard was damaging winds which brought down trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Harrison County law enforcement official reported trees down on Dixie Road near Mauckport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary surface boundary across the region combined with an upper level disturbance coming in from the west produced a round of scattered strong to severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana. The main hazard was damaging winds which brought down trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Harrison County law enforcement official reported trees down along Elizabeth - New Middletown Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe thunderstorms developed across southern Indiana during the afternoon and evening hours August 15th as an upper level system passed through in the presence of a warm and moist air mass.  One particular storm moved through Dubois County and produced damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator reported that severe thunderstorm winds brought down a few trees and power poles in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few thunderstorms developed over northwest Indiana producing hail.
A few thunderstorms developed over northwest Indiana producing hail.

Waves of showers and thunderstorms developed across central Indiana ahead of an approaching cold front during the afternoon and evening of May 30th. The storms brought heavy rain, damaging winds, and one tornado to the area. Some areas of central Indiana received over 4 inches of rain, which caused some flash flooding. Most of the heavy rain and flooding occurred across areas northeast of Indianapolis. The storms also brought damaging winds, which brought down some trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was snapped 10 feet above the base along Highway 231 at Butcher Avenue due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.  Several other trees were down throughout the city.  Some vehicles were damaged from falling tree.  Power was out to the entire city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced localized 60 to 70 mph wind damage in Orange County, Indiana. Dime-sized hail was reported with the storm as it moved east.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed to the NWS a public video of dime size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong to severe quasi-linear convective system dropped southeast out of Wisconsin and intensified as it moved across Lake Michigan. This led to sporadic wind damage, mainly in southwest lower Michigan and northern Indiana, as well as localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down, relayed by county EMA.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Clark County law enforcement official reported trees down in various locations in the eastern part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms fired across northern Indiana in the late afternoon. Strong upper-level forcing was adequate to overcome the relatively weak shear and instability with isolated reports of severe weather.
Storms fired by late afternoon along a stalled baroclinic zone. Moderate instability and shear was sufficient for large hail and a few reports of damaging winds.

Numerous showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of a low pressure center which moved through the area. With moderate instability and shear, numerous severe storms developed with several reports of damaging winds. In addition, storm motion nearly parallel to the frontal boundary caused training storms and localized flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A supercell thunderstorm produced a brief EF0 tornado about 18 miles west of Lafayette or about 2.5 miles southeast of Pine Village in Northern Warren County. The tornado was observed by a trained spotter briefly touching down in a corn field, producing no damage other than to the crops at the touchdown point.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.

Thunderstorms developed in a hot and unstable atmosphere across central Indiana during the afternoon and early evening of July 17th. The storms produced 2 tornadoes in southeast Tippecanoe County along with some hail and strong winds elsewhere. The storms also brought very heavy rain, which resulted in flash flooding in some areas, including parts of the Indianapolis Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS survey revealed EF1 damage with approximately 97 mph winds in the southeast portion of Tippecanoe County, south of the intersection of Highway 52 and County Road 900 South. Observed damage included a collapsed garage, downed trees, and at least one home with vinyl siding removed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold front and associated upper level system swept through the region during the afternoon and evening hours. Abundant moisture, marginal instability and lift from these features caused widespread thunderstorms to develop. A few of these briefly reached severe limits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated wind gusts to 60 mph at the intersection of County Road 125 North and 1000 East.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong spring storm system approached the lower Ohio Valley on April 9th into the early morning hours April 10th. Isolated severe storms that produced damaging winds and hail developed during the afternoon hours before a long-lived line of severe storms approached late in the day into the early morning hours of April 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured a 56 knot wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north-south oriented line of showers and thunderstorms developed across western Indiana as warm, moist air increased across the area during the early afternoon hours of May the 26th. As these storms pushed northeast into east-central Indiana during the middle to late afternoon, one moved over Henry County causing wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One end of a pole barn was pushed in along with several tree limbs downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This event occurred near the intersection of County Roads 200 North and 500 East, east of Hillsboro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northward retreating outflow boundary from morning thunderstorms and eastward migration of upstream instability allowed for convection to fire later in the evening as the cap eroded and an upstream upper level trough approached the region. Storms initially produced isolated hail and wind damage, however heavy rainfall and flash flooding quickly became the primary threat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over State Road 1 at State Road 116 and State Road 124.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through the area on the afternoon of June 7 which advected a moist low level environment into northern Illinois. This increased instability by late afternoon as storms initiated ahead of a cold front across central Illinois. Storms congealed into a multicell cluster and a bookend vorticity formed on the northern edge of the storms. This is where the tornado occurred in Starke County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several 8-12 inch tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two consecutive heavy rain events, combined with snowmelt from the March 4th storm, produced some localized flooding. On the 10th and 11th, widespread showers produced average rainfall amounts around one inch, with isolated places reporting near two inches. Between the 12th and 14th, a storm system developed in east Texas and phased with an upper-level trough moving east through the upper Mississippi Valley. Widespread moderate to heavy rain produced rain totals between 2 and 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall during the past 20 hours was reported to be 1.80 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved into central Indiana during the early morning hours of June 21. These storms produced wind damage across northern sections of the area. Numerous trees and power lines were downed, and some the trees fell on homes causing significant damage. A grain silo was also destroyed by the storms. The storms also brought heavy rain.||A damage survey was done across Tipton County, and the survey determined that straight line winds caused the extensive damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported down in this location due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This report was received via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An early morning thunderstorm complex rapidly developed over the Lower Ohio Valley ahead of a weak mid-level shortwave trough. The complex evolved into a broad zone of convection along and south of a stationary front that extended from central Missouri through central Illinois. Three-hour rainfall amounts were from one to two inches. The convection was focused along the nose of a low-level jet in a very moist air mass, with precipitable water values in the 2 to 2.25 inch range. Unidirectional wind flow from the surface to 500 mb resulted in little net movement of the convection. Although the best instability resided further south in the warm/moist sector, there was enough buoyancy in place to maintain convection. The front settled southward across western Kentucky by late afternoon, providing a focus for renewed convective complexes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The rainfall measured over a ten-hour period was 2.40 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were downed near Minnesota and Meridian Streets due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave trough moving through upper Michigan combined with retreating outflow boundary from morning/early afternoon storms, which moved through northern Indiana/northwest Ohio, spurned new storm development from southern Wisconsin southeast through northeast Illinois by later afternoon. Storms were initially sub-severe and disorganized, but two main bowing segments, one along and north of the Interstate 80/90 corridor and another along the US-30 corridor, developed as cold pool strengthened, causing widespread damaging winds and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs down, with winds estimated at 65 mph on Interstate 94.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak shortwave trough moving through upper Michigan combined with retreating outflow boundary from morning/early afternoon storms, which moved through northern Indiana/northwest Ohio, spurned new storm development from southern Wisconsin southeast through northeast Illinois by later afternoon. Storms were initially sub-severe and disorganized, but two main bowing segments, one along and north of the Interstate 80/90 corridor and another along the US-30 corridor, developed as cold pool strengthened, causing widespread damaging winds and flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees uprooted into a house just north of Plymouth. Time estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of thunderstorms developed in a warm and unstable atmosphere on June 12th. The storms brought heavy rain and damaging winds to portions of central Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 12-inch diameter tree was snapped and two 6-inch diameter trees were blown down due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms, including a few supercells, moved across northwest Indiana producing large hail and at least one brief tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Baseball size hail was reported on the 3900 Block of Hohman Avenue.  Golfball size hail was reported at Indianapolis Boulevard and Michigan Street.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust was observed in this location. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Mainly damaging thunderstorm winds were impacting much of central Indiana during the late morning and early afternoon of July the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were down at the intersection of 86th Street and Zionsville Road due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The last widespread rains of the month were the result of a developing low pressure area that moved through the state on the 26th and early on the 27th. Numerous flooding problems developed quickly across mainly northern sections of central Indiana. People were rescued from cars and homes were flooded in the Muncie area and other areas of east central Indiana. Much of the state along and north of Interstate 70 received 2 to 5 inches of rain. Two individuals perished near Noblesville when their automobile hit water on a road and crashed into a telephone pole.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding occurring on neighborhood roads due to thunderstorm heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Waves of showers and thunderstorms moved across central Indiana on July 13 and into the early morning of July 14. Upper level features interacted with a surface front and plenty of moisture and instability to generate severe weather and heavy rains/flooding. Three tornadoes occurred during the evening of the 13th. One tornado was in Warren County, and the other two were in Putnam County. Widespread tree and power line damage occurred across central Indiana, and some locations received over 4 inches of rain. A few locations had hail as well.  The heavy rain led to flooding in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: White Creek was out of its bank due to moderate to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air mass brought a few rounds of severe thunderstorms to southern Indiana, starting during the evening hours Thursday June 25th. Isolated storms developed first, producing some sporadic wind damage. Then later that night, a complex of organized storms brought damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding during the early morning hours June 26th. Later that same afternoon, a strong surface low pressure moved across central Kentucky and brought another round of severe storms with damaging winds, large hail and flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Harrison County emergency manager reported that a residence on Barren Avenue in Lanesville had 3 feet of water inside as a result of torrential rainfall and slow moving thunderstorms.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of an advancing cold front over eastern Indiana. Additional storms developed on outflows of the mature storms.
An unseasonably strong area of low pressure moved through the Ohio Valley on June 26-27 which brought moderate to heavy rain to the area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain fell in a 24 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall caused high water levels along the Salamonie River, with numerous roads impacted near the river. In addition, several county roads were dealing with high water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a large tree fell onto three phase power lines, breaking at least one power pole and causing scattered power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.

Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local officials reported several tree limbs down in the city of Logansport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a large tree was blown down near Pine Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low was situated over the Great Lakes region. A disturbance moved through the area, helping kick off convection in the early afternoon near the surface-based stationary front. High precipitable waters and limited bulk shear created a good setup for wet microbursts, with some storms producing locally significant wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered strong to severe storms developed on the afternoon and evening of the 4th focused over the eastern half of central Indiana. A measured 70 mph wind gust brought trees and limbs down near Greenfield, and penny to nickel size hail was reported from the eastern Indianapolis suburbs east into Hancock County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and/or utility lines were downed due to damaging thunderstorm wind gusts. This was one of multiple locations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved into the northern Wabash valley late on the evening of the 18th before weakening, producing penny size hail and wind gusts up to 80 mph over parts of Tippecanoe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported in Otterbein just inside Tippecanoe County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe storms moved into the northern Wabash valley late on the evening of the 18th before weakening, producing penny size hail and wind gusts up to 80 mph over parts of Tippecanoe County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured thunderstorm wind gust of 80 mph was observed in this location. Sustained winds were measured at 59 mph at the intersection of State Route 25 North and County Road 900 North.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at the White county airport recorded a 64 mph wind gust as a severe thunderstorm moved through.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.
Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail persisted several minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to widely scattered thunderstorms moved across northeast Illinois and into northwest Indiana during the late afternoon and evening hours.

A low pressure system moved towards northern Illinois during the evening hours, causing thunderstorms to develop in the afternoon and evening hours across northern Illinois and northwest Indiana.  A moist environment helped to produce heavy rainfall across portions of northern Illinois. A brief tornado occurred across the Frankfort-Monee area.  As the storm moved over northwest Indiana hail and wind damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail reported across southern parts of Benton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous down trees and tree limbs form Logansport east.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a car ran over a six foot long, four inch diameter tree limb in the road. The driver suffered minor injuries.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree of unknown size down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous trees and power lines down across Monticello and surrounding areas.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous trees and power lines down in the Indiana Beach area along North County Road 400 East to Shafer Drive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported the roof blown off a hog barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated strong to severe storms associated with an approaching low pressure system moved generally along and south of US-24 in Indiana. Wind damage occurred on more organized storms across White and Cass county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported widespread tree damage in the New Waverly area. Some metal roofing was peeled off a barn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of numerous flooded and impassable roads due to 3 to 5 inches of rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of 5 to 10 water rescues that occurred in Madison as a result of flash flooding. Approximately 5,000 residences and businesses lost power as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall brought flooding to many counties during a couple day period. On average, three to five inches of rain fell, often in a few hours. This rainfall occurred over already saturated ground from recent rains over the past couple of weeks. This resulted in an extended period of runoff and flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of high water and general flooding throughout Plymouth, with several inches of standing water. Other reports of high water were received throughout the county, especially in the Tippecanoe area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over the road on US-30 westbound between SR 105 and Blue River Bridge.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water was covering multiple roads in Brookville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Indiana during the early morning hours July 12th and slowly tracked into southern Indiana shortly before dawn. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain fell in a 1 to 2 hour time frame, resulting in flash flooding across parts of the area. The system was also accompanied by an intense amount of lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that lightning struck the Sulphur Pentecostal Church. According to the Crawford County emergency manager, the church was destroyed and determined to be a total loss.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms associated with an upper level disturbance moved southeast through the Ohio Valley late on the evening of July 13th and into the early morning hours of July 14th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two trees were downed onto State Route 262.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and moist air mass overspread the region in the wake of a warm front that had lifted through the area. This allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop across the Ohio Valley through the afternoon hours. The storms continued into the evening hours, resulting in localized flash flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Showers and thunderstorms associated with an upper level disturbance pushed down into the Ohio Valley during the mid day hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds knocked a large tree limb down onto West 8th Street.

The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clark County emergency manager along with several media outlets reported the drowning of a 67 year old male after he reportedly drove through a flooded roadway. Several inches of rain had fallen during the previous night, flooding a portion of Tunnel Mill Road. His vehicle was found several hours later and a search team discovered his body later that evening.

This allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop across the Ohio Valley through the afternoon hours. The storms continued into the evening hours, resulting in localized flash flooding.
An unseasonably strong area of low pressure moved through the Ohio Valley on June 26-27 which brought moderate to heavy rain to the area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain fell in a 24 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were impacted by an extended period of high water as several rounds of rainfall brought several inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong area of low pressure moved through the Ohio Valley on June 26-27 which brought moderate to heavy rain to the area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain fell in a 24 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were impacted by high water for an extended time as several rounds of rain moved through the area. Flooding was noted in a neighborhood on the southeast side of Auburn. Water was flowing from storm drains and overflowing ponds, with fish swimming down the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong area of low pressure moved through the Ohio Valley on June 26-27 which brought moderate to heavy rain to the area. Between 3 and 6 inches of rain fell in a 24 hour period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds aloft were able to mix down in the rain showers across the area the morning of the 27th. Extremely saturated soils from the excessive rainfall through the month of June made it easy for strong winds of 40-66 mph the morning of the 27th to cause widespread wind damage across the Fort Wayne area. Several dozen trees were uprooted or snapped, and damage was reported as trees fell into houses or on vehicles. The barometric pressure dropped from 29.74 at 754 am to 29.63 at 807 am and then back to 29.74 by 836 am EDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall brought flooding to many counties during a couple day period. On average, three to five inches of rain fell, often in a few hours. This rainfall occurred over already saturated ground from recent rains over the past couple of weeks. This resulted in an extended period of runoff and flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rainfall from the evening of the 15th into the overnight hours of the 16th caused Loon Creek to rapidly increase in level, flooding western portions of Andrews. Water levels rose so rapidly that sand bag operations were not possible. As responders were attempting to sandbag against the rising water, a loud noise was heard with investigation revealing that a railroad bridge over the creek was destroyed with the rail tracks eventually falling into the flood waters. No damage estimates were available, but given the damage to the railroad bridge, figures exceeding $500,000 are likely.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm and unstable air mass allowed for scattered thunderstorm development during the afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northward retreating outflow boundary from morning thunderstorms and eastward migration of upstream instability allowed for convection to fire later in the evening as the cap eroded and an upstream upper level trough approached the region. Storms initially produced isolated hail and wind damage, however heavy rainfall and flash flooding quickly became the primary threat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees down southeast of Portland to the county line. Several are blocking roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Indiana during the early morning hours July 12th and slowly tracked into southern Indiana shortly before dawn. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain fell in a 1 to 2 hour time frame, resulting in flash flooding across parts of the area. The system was also accompanied by an intense amount of lightning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed a report of side street flooding in New Albany. Approximately 1 to 2 inches of rain fell in 60 to 90 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Clark County emergency manager reported several trees across Highway 62 near Nabb.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall brought flooding to many counties during a couple day period. On average, three to five inches of rain fell, often in a few hours. This rainfall occurred over already saturated ground from recent rains over the past couple of weeks. This resulted in an extended period of runoff and flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of rain fell across the county, causing high water in many spots as river, creek and streams attempted to handle all the rainfall. Road closures were reported across portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms developed along a corridor from southern Illinois across northwest Kentucky and southwest Indiana. The storms developed along and just ahead of a weak surface boundary as it drifted southward into a very unstable air mass over the Lower Ohio Valley. Isolated wind damage accompanied the strongest storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two large trees were blown down across South County Road 800 West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small but intense complex of severe thunderstorms developed north of the area but quickly moved into southern Indiana during the evening hours of July 17th. The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported trees and power lines down across the area due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through the area on the afternoon of June 7 which advected a moist low level environment into northern Illinois. This increased instability by late afternoon as storms initiated ahead of a cold front across central Illinois. Storms congealed into a multicell cluster and a bookend vorticity formed on the northern edge of the storms. This is where the tornado occurred in Starke County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS storm survey confirmed an EF-1 tornado embedded within in sporadic wind damage. The tornado touched down in the vicinity of the 6350 block of County Road 400 South and continued east-northeast to the 6250 block of County Road 400 South where four to five dozen trees were either uprooted or snapped. There were no trees left standing in the front yard of this residence. The tornado dissipated shortly after as it turned towards the northwest and continued into the field to the north. The extensive damage in this isolated area was likely associated with the slow forward motion of this tornado as well as wet sandy soil in the area. The tornado was on the ground for around two tenths of a mile with a maximum width of 100 yards and maximum estimated wind speeds of around 95 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of a low pressure center which moved through the area. With moderate instability and shear, numerous severe storms developed with several reports of damaging winds. In addition, storm motion nearly parallel to the frontal boundary caused training storms and localized flooding in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime sized hail was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to ten inch diameter limbs down. A few of the limbs were semi-rotten. A few 2 to 2.5 inch diameter trees are downed. Minor structural damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong to severe quasi-linear convective system dropped southeast out of Wisconsin and intensified as it moved across Lake Michigan. This led to sporadic wind damage, mainly in southwest lower Michigan and northern Indiana, as well as localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: House struck by lightning in 11000 block of Leesburg Road. Caused a delayed fire. The home was a total loss with damages estimated at least $75,000.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small but intense complex of severe thunderstorms developed north of the area but quickly moved into southern Indiana during the evening hours of July 17th. Widespread damaging wind gusts estimated between 55 and 60 mph occurred, resulting in toppled trees and power lines. The Madison, Indiana area was particularly hit hard with damaging winds as well as flash flooding given the very wet conditions in place.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that large trees limbs were snapped off due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms produced heavy rain that resulted in flash flooding across portions of east central Illinois.  An observer near Kentland, Indiana measured 3.33 inches of rain in just two hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Newton County Sheriff reported that there was flooding across much of southern Newton County, mainly south of the Iroquois River, including Kentland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms initiated along a stationary front across northern Indiana. Moderate instability and weak shear led to a few wet downbursts which caused isolated wind damage. The greater threat became flooding as rainfall rates of 2 to 4 inches per hour became common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several county and state roads were covered with water and impassable across the county as two to four inches of rain fell in a few hours, overwhelming local streams, creeks and ditches. Some of the roads impacted included State Route 124, east of State Route 5, County Road 1000 North, east of Meridian, County Road 1000 N east of State Route 5 and near the intersection of State Routes 218 and 105. In addition, water backed up on the Salamonie River, northwest of Warren, where at least a quarter mile long portion of East Flowing Well Road was under water as the flood waters rapidly exceeded the banks of the river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall brought flooding to many counties during a couple day period. On average, three to five inches of rain fell, often in a few hours. This rainfall occurred over already saturated ground from recent rains over the past couple of weeks. This resulted in an extended period of runoff and flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of rainfall caused an extended period of flooding on many of the roads across the county. Even after the rain ended, road closures and evacuations persisted as water levels either remained high or continued to rise after the causative events.  Numerous creeks and ditches ran over their banks adding to the flooding issues. Portions of State Routes 124, 5, 124, 3, 218, 9 all had either high water or water rapidly flowing over the roadways, causing partial or full closures. Several county roads were also impacted. Portions of Roanoke Park were also underwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of upper level disturbances moved from the Upper Midwest into the lower Ohio Valley and interacted with a moist, warm and unstable atmosphere. Strong to severe thunderstorms developed and then organized into bowing segments across the area. The result was damaging wind gusts that toppled trees and power lines. In addition, due to the very wet antecedent conditions, flash flooding occurred on occasion, resulting in closed and impassable roads, water rescues and significant property damage. The hardest hit areas included Jefferson County and the Madison, Indiana areas southwest toward Clark and Floyd counties. Rainfall totals over the period were in excess of 5 to 7 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported that Craigmont St was flooded in Madison.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast media meteorologist relayed a report of flash flooding of roadways near the West Fork Fourteenmile Creek in Clark County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the area during the morning hours of November 21st and became heavy at times in the afternoon. This occurred as a strengthening low pressure system tracked northeast through the region. Snowfall totals generally ranged between 3 and 8 inches, although locally heavier amounts were reported across far northern Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the area shortly after daybreak on November 21st and became heavy at times by late morning and afternoon. There were reports of a few accidents and slide-offs across the region due to reduced visibilities and slushy accumulations on roadways. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 5 and 8 inches, with a report of 6.5 inches 1 mile south-southwest of La Porte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering ridge of surface high pressure over the Ohio Valley provided favorable conditions for dense fog. Visibility was one-quarter mile or less over a widespread area from Evansville north and west.

On the afternoon and evening of November 11, 2015, a strong area of low pressure lifted northeast across Iowa. The storm produced a high wind event across northern Illinois, northwest Indiana and also storm force winds across portions of Lake Michigan. The event continued into the early afternoon of the 12th across northwest Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the intersection of Burr and Old Lincoln Highway. Eight and eleven inch branches snapped off the trunk of a tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and sleet, in combination with gusty winds, created difficult travel and scattered power outages on December 28th. Ice accretions between 0.05 inches and 0.20 inches were common, with sleet accumulations up to near 1 inch in northwest Indiana.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A combination of freezing rain and wind gusts to 40 mph created scattered power outages and downed trees. Slick spots on mainly elevated surfaces also aided in difficult travel and a few accidents. Ice accumulations across the county were generally around a tenth of an inch. The Tippecanoe River State Park was closed for a time due to downed trees and power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first storm of the season for northern Illinois and northwest Indiana left a nearly 300 mile wide swath of snow across portions of the Midwest. Over 16 inches of snow fell across far northern portions of Illinois. Snow began during the late afternoon hours of Friday, November 20th, and persisted through the late afternoon of Saturday, November 21st. ||Some of the highest storm total snow reports include: 9.5 inches near Crown Point  (Lake) and 8.6 inches near Lakes of the Four Seasons (Porter).

South to southwesterly winds through a deep layer of the atmosphere brought copious amounts of moisture from the Gulf of Mexico. A large low pressure system moved slowly north across the Plains. Ahead of an occluded front that arced from the low across the Ozarks, there were two rounds of heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An automated rain gage measured 2.93 inches in the past 48 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Surface high pressure extended from the Ozarks of Missouri to the upper Ohio Valley. Clear skies and light winds provided favorable conditions for widespread dense fog. Visibility was reduced to one-quarter mile or less.

Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front during the afternoon of December 23rd. These storms brought a few tornadoes, straight-line damaging wind reports, and heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EF-1 tornado damage was observed near Smith Valley Road and State Road 135 with winds estimated at 100 mph. Some siding was stripped off one side of a house. Also, the roof was lifted off the back portion of a business.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed ahead of a cold front during the afternoon of December 23rd. These storms brought a few tornadoes, straight-line damaging wind reports, and heavy rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EF-1 tornado damage was observed near Smith Valley Road and State Road 135 with winds estimated at 107 mph. Tree trunks were snapped, an above ground pool was overturned, a portion of a wooden fence was destroyed, large tree branches were downed, and a few homes sustained roof, siding, garage damage.

A front remained near central Indiana during the period December 26 to 28. Unseasonably warm and humid air on the south side of the front combined with the front and an area of low pressure brought periods of rain during the period. Some of the rain was heavy at times. Through the period, central Indiana received 2 to 6 inches of rain.||This resulted in flooding of small streams, creeks, and low lying areas. Some roads were closed due to high water. The water quickly flowed into rivers, resulting in flooding of the rivers. The river flooding impacted numerous local and state roads, agricultural land, and a few residential areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous automated small stream gages in the Indianapolis metro area indicated minor to significant flooding in progress late Sunday morning due to heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A front remained near central Indiana during the period December 26 to 28. Unseasonably warm and humid air on the south side of the front combined with the front and an area of low pressure brought periods of rain during the period. Some of the rain was heavy at times. Through the period, central Indiana received 2 to 6 inches of rain.||This resulted in flooding of small streams, creeks, and low lying areas. Some roads were closed due to high water. The water quickly flowed into rivers, resulting in flooding of the rivers. The river flooding impacted numerous local and state roads, agricultural land, and a few residential areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding due to heavy rainfall on County Road 100 South, just east of County Road 900 East in Hendricks County. Flooding was also observed on County Line Road between County Road 100 South and Highway 40 around 5:30 AM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A squall line developed ahead of an ejecting upper system over the lower Ohio Valley and raced northeast into the region. A second squall line developed and trailed the first one by an hour or so.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm survey was conducted in northeast Wayne County Indiana, in coordination with the Wayne County Emergency Management Agency. Damage began near a property along East Fountain City Pike east of Fountain City, in which several outbuildings were destroyed. Some of the damage followed a southwest to northeast path, although there was evidence of rotation within the debris pattern, which would coincide with a weak tornado. The damage continued in a northeast path and crossed Elliott Road and continued northeast to Bethel. Additional outbuilding damage was surveyed at 2 properties along Elliott Road, in which small outbuildings were destroyed and there was additional damage to larger barns. The path continued northeast to Bethel, where a chimney collapse and roof damage occurred at a church in Bethel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving line of strong to severe storms swept east across southwest Indiana, accompanied by isolated wind damage. A second line of storms moved northeast from western Kentucky across Spencer County, producing an isolated weak tornado there. Conditions were favorable for severe storms. A negatively-tilted mid-level trough from the central high Plains to the Arklatex ejected northeast through the middle Mississippi Valley. At the surface, an area of low pressure over northeast Kansas moved to central Wisconsin. A trailing cold front surged eastward through the Mid-Mississippi and Lower Ohio Valleys. The storms were fed by a broadening and strengthening southwesterly low-level jet, which destabilized the atmosphere ahead of the storms. The presence of strong low-level and deep-layer wind shear enhanced the risk of wind damage and even a tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two semi tractor-trailers were overturned along Interstate 64.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast-moving line of strong to severe storms swept east across southwest Indiana, accompanied by isolated wind damage. A second line of storms moved northeast from western Kentucky across Spencer County, producing an isolated weak tornado there. Conditions were favorable for severe storms. A negatively-tilted mid-level trough from the central high Plains to the Arklatex ejected northeast through the middle Mississippi Valley. At the surface, an area of low pressure over northeast Kansas moved to central Wisconsin. A trailing cold front surged eastward through the Mid-Mississippi and Lower Ohio Valleys. The storms were fed by a broadening and strengthening southwesterly low-level jet, which destabilized the atmosphere ahead of the storms. The presence of strong low-level and deep-layer wind shear enhanced the risk of wind damage and even a tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down along the south side of the city. A billboard was blown over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flooding of the White, Wabash, and Ohio Rivers began late in December and continued into January. A very wet pattern developed during the second half of the month. A large upper-level ridge became established over the eastern half of the country, while a large trough formed over the West. This set up a warm southwest flow that brought in copious amounts of moisture. Around five inches of rain fell in the Evansville area from the 23rd to the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred along the Ohio River. Low-lying woods and fields were inundated. The flooding continued into January.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Unseasonable warmth and rich Gulf moisture collided with an approaching surface low pressure system and cold front to produce several lines of strong to severe thunderstorms across southern Indiana. Damaging winds were the main threat, but hail was also reported. Intense torrential rainfall also fell which produced localized flash flooding issues.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A broadcast meteorologist relayed a report of 1 inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A front remained near central Indiana during the period December 26 to 28. Unseasonably warm and humid air on the south side of the front combined with the front and an area of low pressure brought periods of rain during the period. Some of the rain was heavy at times. Through the period, central Indiana received 2 to 6 inches of rain.||This resulted in flooding of small streams, creeks, and low lying areas. Some roads were closed due to high water. The water quickly flowed into rivers, resulting in flooding of the rivers. The river flooding impacted numerous local and state roads, agricultural land, and a few residential areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Old Paris Road on the Illinois state line was closed due to Sugar Creek flooding from heavy rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Jefferson County emergency manager reported to the NWS that several trees were down in the Hanover area due to severe thunderstorm winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This weak tornado crossed Indiana Highway 161 just a few miles across the Ohio River from Owensboro, Kentucky. The tornado tracked along West County Road 560S to West County Road 440S. Several tree tops were broken, and a 12-inch tree was snapped. Numerous small tree limbs were broken. Peak winds were estimated near 75 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving front combined with very moist air from the Gulf of Mexico resulted in moderate to heavy rain with some thunderstorms during the morning hours December 27th. This rain, which totaled 1 to locally 3 inches, fell on top of already wet and saturated grounds from recent heavy rainfall events, produced localized flooding and flash flooding for portions of the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A law enforcement official reported to the NWS that heavy rainfall resulted in a section of the northbound lane of Highway 231. Drivers were forced to the southbound lane to continue driving.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weather systems impacted the lower Ohio Valley during the last 10 days of December. Rainfall totals varied from 3 to locally 7 inches across much of the river basin, which resulted in significant rises on area rivers, streams and creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain events during the last week of December brought the Blue River at Fredericksburg into minor flood. The river rose reached a crest of 21.17 feet on December 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several weather systems impacted the lower Ohio Valley during the last 10 days of December. Rainfall totals varied from 3 to locally 7 inches across much of the river basin, which resulted in significant rises on area rivers, streams and creeks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain events during late December brought the Ohio River at Tell City into minor flood. The river reached a crest 42 feet during the afternoon on December 30. The river remained above flood stage through the end of December and into the first part of January 2016.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Flooding of the White, Wabash, and Ohio Rivers began late in December and continued into January. A very wet pattern developed during the second half of the month. A large upper-level ridge became established over the eastern half of the country, while a large trough formed over the West. This set up a warm southwest flow that brought in copious amounts of moisture. Around five inches of rain fell in the Evansville area from the 23rd to the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Ohio River rose above flood stage on New Year's Eve. The river crested in early January. There was minor flooding of low-lying fields and woodlands. Some river access roads were underwater.
